speechtext: Mr. FRANK OLIVER (Alberta) moved that the report of the Committee on Standing Orders on a petition of the Right Rev. Tikhon for an Act of incorporation under the name of ' the Bishop of the Orthodox Russo-Greek Catholic Church ' be referred back to the said committee for obtaining their recommendation for the introduction of the Bill, notwithstanding rule 49.

LaRIVIERE (Provencher). This petition lias already been twice referred to the Standing Orders Committee. The first time the committee reported that the rules of the House had not been complied with, and then my hon. friend from Alberta (Mr. Oliver) moved that it be referred back to the said committee for reconsideration. The committee has reconsidered the petition, and instead of amending their first report, they call the attention of the House to further objections to the petition, to the fact that the petitioner is not a British subject, and is not living in the British possessions, but that he is a resident of San Francisco, and an alien, as he admits himself in his petition. Now I do not know whether my hon. friend expects that this committee will stultify itself by making a different report than that which it has already twice made. Moreover, I do not know that the rules of the House will admit that this report may be referred back to the same committee without giving any reasons therefor. There is no reason adduced, there is no instruction asked to be given to the committee. The committee has considered the question twice very attentively, and I may say that the officers of the Crown were present at its meetings. In the first place the Solicitor General (Hon. Mr. Carroll), and in the second place both the Minister of Justice (Hon. Mr. Fitzpatrick)! and the Solicitor General were present, and the last report of the committee was made, in fact, at the suggestion of the Minister of Justice himself. 1 am not usually a supporter of the government, but on this occasion
I think I will have to support them. I am not at all objecting to the incorporation of the Russo-Greek Church, but I think this should be done in a regular way, in such a way that the people who are most interested should know what is taking place. We are asked to incorporate a bishop, a foreigner, who resides in San Francisco, and who claims to be Bishop of the Greek Church in North America and of the Aleutian Islands, he wants to be recognized as such in his petition, and he wants to control the Greek Church in Canada. While my objections are perhaps not relevant to the point of order, I desire to say that in this very important matter we ought to make haste slowly. The committee has taken all these questions into consideration and found everything irregular. The petition itself that came before the Committee on Standing Orders is not even endorsed by the member who presented it to the House, there is no responsible name to the petition, it is irregular in every way, and we cannot expect that the Committee on Standing Orders will stultify itself by reconsidering for the third time a question they have already sufficiently considered. I am not a member of that committee, and, contrary to the statement made by my hon. friend the Minister of the Interior (Hon. Mr. Sifton), I did not take advantage of my position as a member of the committee to bring about the report which was made. I was there as a private member, and I was there as a representative of a portion of the population that it is sought to incorporate without their knowledge. I have one or two thousand of these people In my riding, and it is for that reason that 1 protest against the way things are arranged, and the way in which the incorporation has been sought. I raise the point of order, Mr. Speaker, and I ask your decision upon it.

May I make a statement, or at least give the hon. member some information in regard to the motion that I have made ? I understood him to say that it was indefinite, that the Bill was asked to be reported without consideration. My motion asks that the Bill be referred to the committee for the purpose of getting the committee to recommend' the Bill for the consideration pf the House. We understand that that was the understanding of the House, and I supposed it was the understanding of the committee. There has been a mistake somewhere, I think. The committee has reported on the Bill, but has not reported the Bill, which I understand was the intention of the committee. The report of the Committee on 'Standing Orders may be found on page 338 of the Votes and Proceedings, and is as follows :-
In obedience with the Order of the House of the 15th instant, your committee have again taken into consideration the petition of the Right Reverend Tikhon, of the city of San Francisco, California, bishop of the Orthodox

Russo-Greek Catholic Church, for North America and the Aleutian Islands, for an Act of incorporation. The attention of your committee having been drawn to the fact that the petitioner in this case is, by his own admission, an alien, living in a foreign land, and desiring as such to be created a corporation sale within the Dominion of Canada, they beg to report the same for the information of your House.
. Now I read that report as reporting the Bill to the House. But I am informed that another construction can be placed upon it, and that it does not report the Bill to the House ; and that therefore the Bill is not and cannot properly come before the House without further consideration by the committee. As I read the report the Bill is reported to the House, but in deference to the views of other parties I have to ask the House to refer it back to the committee so that there may be no mistake.

As chairman of the committee, I may say that there is a little misunderstanding. The point having been called to the attention of the committee that the petitioner appeared, on the face of the petition, to be a non-resident of Canada, I understood the committee to decide that the point should be called to the attention of the House and that only, as regards notice the petition is all right, but that the point should be called to the attention of the House; therefore, nothing more was said and the petition was accepted with that understanding. Of course, there was a haziness about it. My own impression . is that when it was considered it was the intention that the petition should go before the House in the usual way and that the committee should simply call the attention of the House to that particular point in order that it might be considered by the House. As far as that point is concerned the committee expresses no opinion, but I think it would be well that it should go back to the committee to have the question settled as to whether the committee intended to recommend the Bill in calling attention to that point.

Mr. Speaker, it is perfectly evident from the proceedings which have come before the House in connection with this Bill, that technical objections are sought to be x'aised as against this Bill for the pui'pose of preventing the House from considering its merits. In the first place we had the objection x'aised as to insufficiency of notice. It went back and it was perfectly evident that the notice was substantially sufficient. When the question of the l'esidence of the petitioner was suggested, it was of course admitted by everybody that it was a question either for the House, itself, to consider, or for the House to consider through its committee on private Bills. But, what is attempted now is to prevent the House from considering that fact altogether. This House, itself, Mr. OLIVER.
either in proper session, or through its committee on private Bills, ought to consider objections such as those that have been raised. If the objection to the considei'a-tion of this Bill be l'aised under a rule of the House, then, it is quite clear, that it is not customary to enforce that rule. The precedents upon the subject are quite clear. I would ask your attention, Mr. Speaker, to Bourinot, page 320 :
Aliens, not resident in this country, have strictly no right to petition parliament. In the case of applications for private bills, however, this rule is not enforced. It was agreed in ISIS, at the suggestion of Mr. Speaker Anglin, to receive a petition from the Hartford directors of the Connecticut Mutual Insurance Company, on the ground that it was a mutual company, partly composed of Canadians, and that it was the subject of parliamentary legislation, the company being required to make a certain deposit before doing business in the country. Iu 1883, a petition from certain persons in the city of Portland ir. the state of Maine, asking for an Act of incorporation, was received on the ground that the subject matter came within the jurisdiction of the House, as in the case already cited. The reception of such petitions may be considered as an act of grace.
While a petition has been presented and has gone to the Committee on Standing Orders, I understand that the members of the committee and the promoter of the Bill understood that the Bill was being reported to the House. After It had gone to them, as was quite proper, it was called to the attention of the committee that the petitioner was an alien and they desired to call the attention of the House to the fact, so that the House might consider it and might, in its judgment, agree to the usual grace being extended to this petition. I submit that the House ought not to put this petitioner in the position of not being able to get before ns at all. Having complied with the rules so far as notice is concerned, having done everything that the law requires him to do, and the Bill having been passed upon by the Standing Orders Committee, he should be put in the position of being able to come before the House and of having it decided by the House whether his Act of incorporation should be passed or not. Certainly, he has that right, and every person who comes asking for legislation has that right. If this House decides that it will not extend the usual grace to him but that on the ground that he is an alien it will refuse to give him the legislation which he requires, and I am not going to assume that the House will decide in that way at all, he certainly has a right to have a decision from the House. If it be necessary under tbe terms of the report, as the bon. member for Alberta (Mr. Oliver) has read it-that is a matter upon which yon, Mr. Speaker, will rule-if it be necessary that the Bill shall go back to the Standing Orders Committee in order that the committee may amend this report, I submit, that it is only fair and just to the petitioner that he should

have a decision from this House on the merits of his Bill.	.
speakername: The MINISTER OF THE INTERIOR (Hon. Clifford Sifton).

speechtext:
I think there is only one matter before the House and that is : Does the report convey what the committee agreed to ? I certainly understood that the committee was to report the Bill with the statement that they did this for the information of the House, because the petitioner had, In the petition, represented himself as a citizen of the United States, and that the matter would come up In connection with the Bill. Cer-tainy, I agree that the Bill should not be left with the committee without coming back at all. The question is : Does the report of the committee bring back the Bill to this House ? I think it is very doubtful.
1 think that while I would inquire into the standing of this man that the Bill ought to come back here as the committee agreed and then we will take action. I do not say that I will vote for the Bill, but, if it comes back, it will come back from the committee, and, as I understand, they were to report on the Bill, adding the words that were there. As we have had the report the committee do not report the Bill at all. I think we should have the Bill reported.

Objection is raised to this motion which has been made by the hon. member for Alberta (Mr. Oliver) and which demands that the report of the committee presenting this petition shall be referred back to the Committee on Stand-Orders. If I understand the situation, a petition was presented some time ago by this reverend gentleman, and was received by the House. The petition has been actually received by the House and has been referred to the Standing Orders Committee. Now, I think also that the petition, even though it be signed by an alien, can be received by this House if the House is disposed to receive it. I see that in many instances, especially concerning private Bills, petitions signed by some aliens have been received. This petition has been before the Standing Orders Committee, a report has been made upon it and the report according to the motion is not satisfactory. I think that the motion to refer back that report to the committee is absolutely in order.

The only thing referred to this House is a particular fact regarding the Bill, and the Bill is before the committee yet to report on it or not as they see fit - In view of this, I submit with great respect that this motion is entirely irregular. The committee have not technically reported on the Bill, but only on a fact in connection with it, and the House can deal with that or not as they see fit. I submit that there is) nothing in the world to prevent the committee proceeding to deal with this Bill just as if this fact had not been reported to the House.
Motion agreed to.
I wish to give notice that I will move to-morrow the motion which stands in my name.
I thought the Minister of Railways was to make his statement to-morrow.
speakername: The PRIME MINISTER (Rt. Hon. Sir Wilfrid Laurier).

speechtext: Not until after the committee reports.
Very well.

The MINISTER OP THE INTERIOR (Hon. Clifford Sifton) moved for leave to introduce Bill (No. 119) to further amend the Yukon Territory Act. He said :	The
first section of this Bill changes the wording of the clause which gives the Commissioner ini Council of the Yukon territory jurisdiction, and the effect of the change is that in case of a conflict between an ordinance passed by the Governor in Council and an ordinance passed by the Commissioner in Council, the ordinance passed by the Governor in Council shall prevail. It is simply for -the purpose of avoiding unnecessary litigation where there is a dispute in regard to jurisdiction. The Bill also gives the local council of the Yukon territory the control and regulation of [DOT] the sale of intoxicating liquors in the territory. It will be observed by -the House that that clause does not affect the section in the Act which deals with the manufacture of liquor in the Yukon territory. The second section refers to the sittings of the court. The third section makes an important change in connection with the local council of the territory. It is the view of the government that matters have now arrived at the stage at which a further measure of representative government may be extended to the Yukon territory, and it is therefore provided in accordance with the application of the Yukon council :	That instead of two
elected representatives in the local council thel'e shall hereafter be five. The fourth section of the Bill amends the clause which relates to the powers of the Governor in Council respecting the territories. The amendment as drawn removes the prohibition as against the Governor in Council imposing a tax in that territory, but I desire to explain to the House that this clause was drafted by error, and I will ask an amendment to be made, the exact terms of which I will announce on the second reading of the Bill.

The MINISTER OF THE INTERIOR (Hon. Clifford Sifton) moved for leave to introduce Bill (No. 120) to amend the Dominion Lands Act. He said:	I need not
explain in detail the different sections of this Bill, but the purport of it and the effect of it if passed will be :	To provide
that hereafter sales of land and homestead entries which may be granted in the Northwest Territories shall foe subject to the provision that the government of the Northwest Territories may open a road not more than 60 feet wide and comprising not more than 5 per cent of the particular parcel of land in question, without paying anything for the right of way. That is to say : Homestead entries and sales shall be subject to the right of the government of the North-west Territories to open a road across the lands sold. It is found that a large number of roads have to be opened by the government other than on the road allowances, and the difficulty of opening these roads is largely increased toy demands for compensation for the right of way. I have thought that we should assist them to the best of our ability by providing that hereafter, lands when sold shall be subject to *the right of the North-west government to open a road without paying anything for the right of way. The details are worked out in the Bill. There was formerly a similar provision with respect to the right of way of the Canadian Pacific Railway so that there, is no special difficulty in practice in working this arrangement out.
Motion agreed to, and Bill read the first time.

Mr. RALPH SMITH (Vancouver) moved for leave to introduce Bill (No. 122) to fur-Hon. Mr. SIFTON.
ther amend the Act to restrict the importation and employment of aliens.
Explain.

The object of the amendment which I propose by this Bill, is to put the enforcement of the Alien Labour Act in charge of the Minister of Labour, instead of the Attorney General as now. I propose to amend the Act so as to give effect to section 6. The House will remember that since certain amendments were made to the Alien Labour Act last session, the government have interpreted the law to mean that they have nothing at all to do with the enforcement of the Act. The amendment in this Bill will give effect to section 6, so that the government will be called upon to send, out their commissioner at the request of the labour unions to investigate any complaint with regard to the importation of alien labour into the country, and to report on each case, and if necessary deport them.
Motion agreed to, and Bill read the first time.

House in Committee on Bill (No. 69) respecting the Canadian Pacific Railway Company-Mr. Guthrie.
On section 11,

That section 11 of the said Bill be amended by striking out the words, 'at such rates as may be fixed by agreement.'
He said : I do not wish to detain the committee ; but this section incorporates the railway company as an irrigation company. I have no objection to that whatever ; but as the only irrigation district in Canada is within the constituency which I represent and the adjoining constituency, I feel bound to be satisfied as to what the law is in regard to irrigation in that district. It seems to me that the words which I have moved to strike out conflict with the general Irrigation Act, chapter 33 of 1898, section 51 of which provides that ' the minister may regulate from time to time the water rates which may foe charged by licensees, and the publication of tariffs of rates.' My contention is that if we empower the company specifically in this Act to charge such rates as may be agreed upon, we relieve them from the control of the general Irrigation Act in that particular, which I need hardly say is

the most important provision in the Act. Iam anxious to have this question clearly decided before allowing the section to pass. If the words of the section do not conflict with the provision in the general Act, then I wish to withdraw all opposition to it ; but if there is a possibility of these words conflicting with that vital power in the general Act, then I would respectfully ask that they be struck out.

The power to be conferred by section 11 of this Bill is, I understand, to be exercised wholly within the district of Alberta, and the district which I represent.
I may say that I have no objection to urge generally. On the contrary, I am very pleased to know that a strong company like the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, having financial ability, has in contemplation the construction and operation of irrigation works, likely to largely promote the development of the country. But while I have no objection to the Canadian Pacific Railway Company obtaining the powers of an irrigation company, I have objection to them being put in a position different from that of other irrigation companies already organized, or which may hereafter be organized. Other companies are under the general irrigation laws subject to public control of rates. It may be that the words which we move to strike out of section 11 do not relieve the Canadian Pacific Railway Company from such control, but if the words do not have this effect, then it seems to me they are wholly unnecessary. At all events they may serve to cast a doubt, and give rise to difficulty. If the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, as an irrigation company, is to be exactly on the footing of other companies, the words which we wish to be struck out are unnecessary.

This matter was fully considered when the Bill was in committee, and if lion, members will study the clause they will find that it only applies to lands now owned by the Canadian Pacific Railway. As regards their own lands the company can surely claim the right, which any individual enjoys, of making what agreements they please for the furnishing of water, but the moment they seek to go off their own lands, or in what are known as the even number sections, the general Irrigation Act will apply to them as well as it does to other companies. The saving clause which defines the whole position is the following :
At such rates as may be fixed by agreement, and for the purposes aforesaid, generally exercise the powers of irrigation.
That puts it beyond reasonable doubt that the moment that company seek to irrigate lands not their own they will come within the scope of the general Act.

The ownership of lands does not relieve the owner from the control of the government in the sale or disposal of
the water, which is specifically declared by the Act to be the property of the Crown. The owner is given the privilege of selling that which belongs to the public, but only at such a price as may be fixed by the Minister of the Interior. It makes no difference, under the general Act, who owns the land. The point is that the country owns the water and has the right of fixing the rates at which that water shall be sold, and when you allow the Canadian Pacific Railway to fix its own rates, you are relieving it from the general operation of the Act and enabling it to sell public property at such figures as it may choose to fix, thus giving it a privilege by statute over every other irrigation company. That is absolutely contrary to the spirit and intention of the Irrigation Act.

IVhen this matter came up before the Railway Committee it had not previously attracted my attention, and when the general proposition was advanced by some member of the committee that this company, as an irrigation company, would be subject to the general Irrigation Act, I felt that except, in so far as the company might by statute be exempted from the operation of that Act, the proposition was well stated, and, in a general way, I expressed my assent to the statement of the law as made. On further consideration I am inclined to modify the view I then expressed as respects this particular portion of the clause. The company, it is true, has only asked for powers to construct irrigation works upon its own property, but the concluding portion of section 11 contemplates that the water which it may conduct through its own property, it may dispose of to municipalities or individuals who may own property adjoining or contiguous to that of the company, or be within reach of the company's operations. In that case it does not strike me that the company is simply providing water to persons who may occupy its own property but is obtaining a general irrigating power. And when they do so supply all persons outside, I' would think it only reasonable and just that the provisions of the general law should apply, which says that the rates shall be fixed in accordance with its provisions. In that view, the words which are proposed to be struck out by the motion, it seems to me, might properly be struck out, so I support the amendment. I think there is no difficulty or trouble at all likely to arise from that, because the provisions of the general law are ample to enable this company which is supplying the general public to do so under as favourable circumstances as any other irrigation company that may be incorporated.

speechtext:
House in committee on Bill (No. 73) to incorporate the North Shore Power, Railway and Navigation Company.-Mr. McCarthy.
On the preamble,

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: Has this Bill anything to do with the North Shore Navigation Company ?

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: Not the slightest.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: Are not the terms somewhat confusing ? There is already a company incorporating the North Shore Navigation Company.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: Their place of business is going to be down east of the Saguenay, 300 miles below Quebec. I don't think there is any chance of their coming into conflict.

speechtext:
Not the slightest.
On section 6,
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: I think these are altogether too wide powers to give to any company. Everything under the sun is takenin.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: I could not hear what the hon. gentleman (Mr. Rosamond) said. I am in charge of the Bill if the hon. gentleman wants any explanations.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: What explanation or excuse is there for giving such extensive powers to this company ? About every trade and business in the country is to be carried on by this company.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext:
The power, as far as manufacturing industries is concerned, is limited to the territory east of the Saguenay river on the north shore of the St. Lawrence. The territory is an absolute wilderness. The incorporators of this company have purchased about GOO miles of limits, they have acquired a water power on the Marguerite river and their business opera-Hon. Mr. BLAIR.
tions will be carried on at Bay of Seven Islands. That company is going into a district in which there is no habitation, which is an absolute wilderness and it will have to develop as it goes ahead. While the powers which it asks for are considerable, I think the hon. gentlemen will agree with me that, having regard to the circumstances, they are not too great. They will enter there and they will immediately have to put up a saw mill and a pulp mill as the limits will require both a saw mill and a pulp mill. They may find in that district clay out of which they can make brick and tile and they require the power that is given in the Bill for the purpose of enabling them to manufacture their own brick for the erection of buildings and other uses. They may find certain kinds of ore which can be manufactured there. Perhaps my hon. friend will agree with me when I say, that if they take sheep down there and find that they propagate and increase they may be allowed to sheer these sheep and manufacture the wool into material for the clothing of their employees.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: What about the cotton mills ?

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: I do not know that they have discovered any cotton in that district. Having these matters in view the committee did not think the powers they were conferring upon this company were too great ; in fact it was stated, that people who have the nerve to put their money into an enterprise of this kind and purchase the licenses and the territory upon which they are going to operate, asking no concessions from any body, ought to be encouraged to the fullest extent.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: We should encourage them, but it seems to me that these powers are very extensive. I do not know all about that district, but it is a very wealthy district. There is very large mineral and timber wealth and I think there are companies already organized to work in that district. Although we must give the greatest encouragement to parties who are willing to invest their capital down there, we must not lose sight of the fact that this is a very rich district in natural resources. If my hon. friend (Mr. McCarthy) reads section 6 he will find that this company is authorized to do almost anything-build canals, for instance. Where will these canals be built ?

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: That is only for power purposes. The company's works are on the river six miles from the Bay of Seven Islands.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: I am very glad to see a company extending its operations down there but I am afraid that these powers are tco various and too numerous.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: Speaking as an Ontario member I may say that we are very sorry to lose them.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: I think it would be simpler to enumerate two or three things that the company may not do and say that it may do everything else. I do not observe any restrictions upon the operations of this company at all. My hon. friend (Mr. McCarthy) says they are restricted to a particular area. Where is that ?

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext:
It is in the amendment,
*-east of the Saguenay river on the north shore of the St. Lawrence.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: If you go far enough east on the Saguenay river you can come round to it again and that practically takes in the whole earth.

speechtext:
It seems to me absolutely unrestricted as to territory. Take only one of these clauses in the Bill and you will find a numerous variety of things in which this company may engage :	The
company may :
(b.) carry on the business, in all its branches, of manufacturing pulp wood, pulp, paper and all other business incident thereto ; and also the business of manufacturing and burning of bricks, tiles, drain pipes, terra cotta and other materials from clay ; and also the business of general merchants and general contractors ; and also the business of general luanufactux-ers, millers, common carriers, wharfingers, warehousemen, and may construct, charter, acquire and navigate steam and other vessels between any port and place in Canada, and any other port or place in Canada or elsewhere ;
This is only one of many sections.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: If my hon. friend (Mr. Borden, Halifax) would like to discuss the Bill clause by clause I think I could satisfy him.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: I think some special reason ought to be advanced for giving a company such an enormous variety of powers.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: I would ask my hon. friend (Mr. Borden, Halifax) what possible objection, from a public standpoint, there can be to giving these powers to a company to carry on the business enumerated iu that clause ?
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES (Hon. James Sutherland).

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: I would ask my hon. friend (Mr. Sutherland) a question. Why not incorporate the company under some general form of this kind : The company may carry on any business it sees fit in any part of tiie world ? Would the hon. gentleman think that a desirable class of legislation ?

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext:
We have not that power. As far as Canada is concerned, in my humble opinion, an enterprise of this kind must prove a public benefit. It is always difficult for me
to understand why, when a Bill comes before the House incorporating a company which is raising capital to develop the country in a legitimate business way, there should be so much discussion and so much opposition to it. I believe it would be in the interest of the companies and in the interest of the public if we were to incorporate companies of this kind in a very simple way, making them subject to the laws of the country. I believe that almost every limitation is against the interests of the public and I believe that legislation interfering with enterprises of this kind which is supposed to be in the interest of the public and against the interests of the corporation, is very frequently against the interests of the public. Such limitations are uot imposed upon companies in other countries doing business here. These companies, if they go on at all, simply go on by evading the law if the limitation put upon them is fo-und to hamper their operations too severely. I feel very much interested in this class of legislation and I shoulu like to know why we should not follow the example of England and the United States and give more liberal terms to companies like this which are investing their capital and carrying on a legitimate business in the country.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext:
I presume that the powers conferred on this company could have been conferred upon it by tbe legislature of Quebec. It need not have come here at all for these powers and I take it that this House will be chiefly interested in securing the rights of the Dominion in this territory. There are very many parts of Quebec in which there are waterways and other resources of value to Canada as a whole, that might possibly be interfered with to the detriment of any similar company.
' The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES. I do not know if there is anything of that kind.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: As long as these interests are safeguarded I think the conferring of these powers would be all right.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext:
I think this Bill must have been before tbe Miscellaneous Private Bills Committee and that it did not get so far as the Railway Committee, because I have been attending the Railway Committee-
Mr. McCarthy. It is reported from the Private Bills Committee.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: Then, I am right in my conjecture. My interest in the Bill before the committee is as to how far the railway portion of it has been properly safeguarded. 1 see that power is taken also to * maintain, construct, use and operate canals.' That language is very general.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext:
It is limited to the country below the Saguenay.

You will not be able to build any canals down there.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: I see also that the Bill states that the Railway Act is not to be applicable. If that has been amended so as to include the application of such provisions of the Railway Act as would be proper and necessary, I would not have any serious objection to the Bill.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: That section is amended.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: I have seen the Bill since it came to the House, and I do not see that the ordinary clauses of the Railway Act which are made applicable to railway undertakings apply in this Bill, but only certain amendments which were made to the general Railway Act in 1890.
speakername: The MINISTER OP RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: That is so. If the members of this committee understood the conditions under which this company will be called upon to operate, they would realize that there is nothing dangerous in the powers conferred in this Bill. The operations of the company are limited to that territory on the north shore of the St. Lawrence which is east of the Saguenay river. That means that they are going into a country that is at the present time almost absolutely a barren desert.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: Not barren.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: I have fished and hunted over this part of the country and there is not one inhabitant to a hundred square miles. Perhaps the word barren does not apply, but there is practically nothing there except timber, minerals and fish. There is, however, in that district possibly the best harbour on the St. Lawrence, east of Quebec, and known as the Bay of Seven Islands ; a bay which is 25 miles wide, and which is the only harbour of refuge on the north shore of the St. Lawrence east of Tadousac. These gentlemen have bought 1,000 miles of limits down in that territory and it is their intention to develop these limits. They have also acquired a very extensive water power. Up to the present time, almost all the pulp wood of that territory has been exported to the United States, but the intention is to populate that country so that we may manufacture our own timber into pulp. They must have means to export that pulp. This territory is absolutely inaccessible for seven months in the year, and for the other five months it is only accessible by water, there being a bi-monthly service by steamer from Quebec. The territory of this company does not extend as far as the Bay of Seven Islands but they have acquired a stretch of land fronting on the hay where they propose to build wharfs, and to which they

speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: wish to have communication by a railway, ten or twelve miles long, in order that they may bring their pulp down to the harbour. A mile, or a mile and a half back from the shore there is nothing but mountains, so that this short railroad must run alongside the shore. It is absolutely necessary that they should have tills railway to the Bay of Seven Islands in order to export the products of their mills. I said that the country was barren, and I was perhaps very properly corrected by my hon. friend from Jacques Cartier (Mr. Monk). The country is not barren, but it is practically uninhabited and it will be necessary for the company to bring people down there and to provide them all the necessaries of life. They therefore ask to have a grist mill, to have a farm, and to have all these things which are necessary to start this new company in a country which at the present time affords absolutely no facilities for business. While these powers may appear extraordinary, I would remind the House that they are limited to this territory on the north shore of the St. Lawrence east of the Saguenay, and the company is not going to enter into serious competition with industries in other parts of Canada. Suppose that even they had power to operate a cotton mill, they could not compete with cotton mills elsewhere. I would point out that last year this House gave just as extensive powers to the Ottawa and Hull Power Company, and moreover, they gave to that company the right to operate throughout the whole of Canada and elsewhere.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: What Bill was that ?

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: Chapter 108, 1 Edward VII. In view of the fact that we have limited the operations of this company to the territory I have, described, and in view also of the precedent created last year, I think we can well afford to let this Bill go through.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: I do not wish to be understood as endeavouring to create any difficulty about the passing of this Bill. It may be quite true that this territory is comparatively unpeopled to-day and there may be no town or villages and no public highways, but if there be even one public highway it is liable to be crossed by the railway.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: Draw the amendment the way you want it.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: The railway is only ten miles.	.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext:
But ten miles of railroad may cross at least one highway, and there are strong reasons why it should be subjected to the Railway Act. There may be many highways 3 or 4 years hence, and we are

creating a railway corporation with power to obstruct the highways, and we ought to see, in granting that power, that the company is made subject to all the provisions which govern railways.
speakername: The MINISTER OP RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: I would suggest as to section 15, which provides that the Railway Act shall not apply to the company, the words be added 1 except as respects the company's undertaking.'

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: Does not the Minister of Justice think some of these clauses are a little too general ? I am glad to see that this company has succeeded in acquiring a thousand square miles of territory, because, although not inhabited much at present, it is a very rich territory. 1'here is a pulp industry at Chicoutimi which sells its whole output to England at $18 a ton, and I think it is kept very busy. Here is a clause which states that ' the company may construct, acquire, use, maintain and operate canals, watercourses, raceways, and water powers, and construct dams, sluices, conduits and buildings in connection therewith.'

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: Let that power be limited, if you wish, to be exercised in connection with their enterprise.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext:
They have also power ' to lease and acquire rights and privileges with respect to fisheries and fishing in the waters of the St. Lawrence river and gulf and streams emptying therein.' I question very much if that clause would satisfy what population there is down there. We may find this company in the position of those two powerful companies which acquired such large fishing rights in Gaspe that they are considered to-day to be a considerable deterrent to the advancement of the county.
Mr. McCarthy. I move that subsection ' j ' be amended by adding the words ' in connection with their undertaking.'

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext:
The hon. gentleman in charge of this Bill mentioned that the company are bringing down sheep, and that they propose starting a woollen factory. I think there must be an omission from that clause, because if they bring down the sheep, it would be well for them to make provision for tanning the sheepskins. Therefore, I would suggest that a tanning business be added.
Mr. McCarthy. I have no objection.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext:
I would like to ask the promoter of this Bill whether he seriously means us to carry sub-clause ' d, ' which provides that the company may carry on the business of farming and, stock-raising. I do not know that this parliam'ent is accustomed to license companies to carry on a farming business. I have heard with a good deal of interest what the Minister of 99
Justice saidiabout the country being uninhabited, ; but I protest against this company going into an uninhabited country aud doing all the farming there instead of bringing in immigrants. Apparently no immigrant can go into that country to engage in farming unless he deals with this corporation. I think we ought to have some restriction placed upon this company, that will bring in the policy of the immigration department of this government, so that we may know whether immigrants are to be excluded from going into that uninhabited country, unless they make such arrangements with this company as it thinks fit. It seems to me that this is nothing but a hugh trust or monopoly for that part of the country.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: Will my hon. friend explain what he means when he says that this company is a trust ? The Bill authorizes the company to run a farm.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: I ask you to restrict this company so that it will not have power to prevent any one else going there to farm.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: My trouble is to understand what is in this Bill to prevent any one going there to farm.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: There is but one clause that prevents it. You ought to embody in the Bill a provision that the company may engage in banking.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: They have a good substitute for money in that part of the country, where the people use little bits of paper called pitons. I cannot see anything in the Bill which prevents a man going there to farm. It simply gives the company the right to farm, but does not prevent any one else doing so.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: This is the first time I have known any incorporated company to be given that power.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext:
This company, 1 think, owns a thousand miles of land. Will any hon. gentleman tell us what possible objection there is to allowing it to farm that land ; or if there are any minerals there, to its being allowed to mine or smelt them ; or, if there is timber, to its being allowed to cut that timber or manufacture it into pulp. What reason is there for preventing the company utilizing their thousand miles of territory in any may they possibly can ? These gentlemen, by going into the state of New Jersey and filing their application, could have created themselves into a legal entity, and could have come here and done everything they ask for power to do under this charter. Or they could have gone to Nova Scotia and done the same thing or, I understand, in Ontario, under the Joint Stock Companies Act. Certainly they could do so with us, or they could have gone down to Maine and
REVISED EDITION *

have got it. Is there any objection to their working that property in every possible way, I do not care how, that will make it most productive. Hon. gentlemen make objections to this kind of charter but they do not say what their objections are or what hardship or possible wrong can be accomplished under it.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: I assume of course that this company will have an exclusive right, and that no other company or individual will be able to operate without its consent, because the company owns the land and can prevent anybody else going upon it. It seems to me then that it makes very little difference to us what power we grant it. But it is quite possible that when this company secures incorporation, it may not carry out more than a very small fraction of the powers we are giving it. It is difficult for us to know, when Bills of this kind are introduced, just what the intention is, and I have no doubt that a great many Bills are drawn up in this way, with the intention of misleading the House and causing us to believe that the parties seeking incorporation are going to do a great many things, when they only intend doing two or three. The company asks power to carry *on the business of lumberers, timber merchants and manufacturers of timber and lumber in all its branches. That gives it the power to cut all the timber on its territories and possibly it will do nothing more. For my part, I do not believe it will enter into one-twentieth part of all the other undertakings, for which it seeks incorporation, and therefore I think we should limit its powers as far as possible and have them exclusively exercised for the benefit of Canadians. One restriction we should put into this Bill would be to prevent this company from exporting a single stick of pulp wood, and compel it to do all its manufacturing in this country. When it is asking for such extraordinary powers, we should hedge our grant around with everything that will compel the company to give the country something back in return instead of simply carrying away our natural products. The power in the first section will enable the company to cut all the timber on its property and export it from the country-to put as little labour into it as possible, and distribute as little money as possible in the country, which possibly would be the most profitable way for the company to conduct its operations. Before giving the company such extraordinary powers as it asks for, we should insist on some limitation in the interests of the people. I would suggest that the promoter of the Bill should agree to the insertion of a clause, which will prevent the export of pulp wood from this territory to any foreign country, and will oppose the Bill unless that be done.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: So far as the timber products of the company are concerned, they are entirely within the purview of the local

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext:
government. When any one, obtains the right to cut timber from a local government, he purchases that right subject to any restrictions which the local government may deem fit to impose from time to time. The ' Ontario government, for instance, some time ago prevented the export of pine logs, and altered the licenses they had given in this respect. There was a lawsuit, but the alteration was sustained, so that any man who purchases timber limits does so subject to the conditions and regulations of the Crown Bands Department of the province. Thus the purchase by this company from the Quebec government is subject to the regulations and conditions which that government may impose, and that government may impose an export duty on any pulp wood exported and not manufactured" in the territory. I am informed, however, by my right lion, friend the Prime Minister that in the province of Quebec the license holders have to pay so much timber dues on the wood they cut, but if that wood is manufactured in the province, they are allowed a rebate. In Ontario the license holders have no right to export pine logs, and I think the same regulation applies also to pulp wood. When a lumber merchant purchases, as those seeking incorporation have done, he does so subject to the regulations and conditions imposed by the Minister of Crown Lands in the province of Quebec, so that I do not see why this House should interfere in the, direction suggested.
I might further add that the parties seeking incorporation have told me that their intention is to proceed at once to erect a large saw mill and pulp mill on the territory they have purchased and build up a large industry there. I may tell my hon. fwend that his statement that these powers are asked for in order to mislead parliament is entirely incorrect. It is necessary for people who are developing a country to have these powers. The hon. gentleman well knows that when the Sault Ste. Marie Company was incorporated, it began operating in pulp. Then the proprietors discovered mineral wealth in their territory, and immediately began developing that. Then they found that they required ships for navigation purposes, and immediately began to develop in that direction. All those who have gone into the work of developing the country have learned by experience that it is necessary they should obtain the powers mentioned in this Bill. It is most important that this company should have the right to acquire ships-more so than it is to the Sault Ste, Marie Company, because there is at present only bimonthly trips by steamer to that locality and ships do not call regularly there, and probably could not be induced to go there. These people will require the necessary ships to transport their supplies and materials in and the manufactured products out, and I do not think that we ought to curtail the powers they are asking. The ineor-

porators of tliis company are all Canadians but one. The two first named gentlemen are old Toronto men who went to New York and made money there in the paper business aud who desire to develop largely the territory they have acquired. One of them is a United States citizen, but the other is still a Canadiau. The other members of the company are all Toronto men of substantial means. These people have paid their money for the limits and are going to a territory, which is now practically a wilderness, for the purpose of developing it as Canadians and for Canadians.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext:
I observe that.
Mr. McCarthy. If they do manufacture pulp to a large extent, they will probably require their own ships to bring the product to the English and European markets.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext:
I do not regard that incidental consideration as a sufficient justification for the interference of this parliament. I do not know what proof was laid before the committee that it is absolutely necessary that this company, which is entirely in the embryo at present-
Mr. McCarthy. It is only in the embryo as regards its charter. It has acquired and paid for all this territory.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext:
These gentlemen have not yet commenced to manufacture so that the company, as regards its operations, is still entirely in the embryo, and I would not suppose that it was an absolutely necessary incident of a company formed for this purpose, that it should own its own ships. But if that be the case, the proper mode would be to go the provincial legislature, which has primary jurisdiction over this matter, namely, the legislature of Quebec, and seek incorporation there in the first instance. And then, when the company has been formed, if it is necessary that it should have this power, let it come and get that incidental power from this parliament. That has been done in many cases in the past and is the proper way to legislate, it seems to me. For, what we are doing is this-in order to grant an incidental power, such as is mentioned by the hon. gentleman and which may never be exercised by the company at all, we are invading the jurisdiction of the legislature -of the province of Quebec, and, without 994	.
giving any voice to the representatives of the people of that province in their legislature, we are dealing with a great multitude of subjects which are properly matters to be considered by the legislature and not by the Dominion parliament at all. I would like to know from the right hon. gentleman who leads the House (Rt. Hon. Sir Wilfrid Laurier) whether he regards this as a good mode of legislation. I raised this question once before during the present session and gave my opinion that the proper mode was to go to the provincial legislature for such powers as they could give, and not for this parliament to seize jurisdiction from them.
I have not changed my mind on this subject, but so far as I have been able to give consideration to the matter, that seems to me the proper way. For otherwise you usurp the functions of the provincial legislature by dealing with ninety-nine things that they could properly deal with on the plea that there is one subject concerning which the company wishes powers and which can be dealt with only by this parliament.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext:
The organization of capital for the development of industry is one of the latest achievements of civilization. It is quite within the memory of hon. members present that companies could not be incorporated except by an Act of parliament. Men who wished to associate for the purpose of carrying on business had to come to the legislature to get their powers. It was found, after this had been carried on for some time, that no danger would be incurred, and, on the other hand every good purpose would be served if, instead of parliament dealing with these matters, power were delegated to the government. An Act was passed in this country following similar Acts passed in the mother country and elsewhere, giving the government power to grant charters for certain purposes. That Act has been in force for about twenty-five years. Now it is found too cumbrous, and a Bill has been introduced in another branch of the legislature to facilitate the creation of corporations. For my part, I cannot see what objection there can be to granting to any corporation the amplest powers to engage in business which will develop the country. I can see that there is one ground for restriction, and that is that no company should be granted a monopoly. When the question of granting a monopoly arises, that introduces another principle. But I cannot see why this company should not be organized to do business in pulp, to engage in navigation or to do anything in the way of that kind of business, especially in such a territory as that which is to be the scene of this company's operations. If there were danger that this company would come into conflict with existing interests, we should carefully study its nature, but so far as I know7 the provisions of the Bill, no mono-

poly is given. We give this company power to carry on its business, but I do not know any reason wliy another company cannot go into business right alongside o'f it. What wrong is done then, and what danger is involved to the interests of anybody ? I do not see that any good purpose would be served by refusing this incorporation, and, on the other hand it seems to me such a refusal might restrict the development of the country and put a damper upon the use of capital. I have followed the discussion with care, but have not heard any suggestion that there is a monopoly granted. But, if there is, we ought to attend to it. If the only objection is that the powers are too large and cover too many industries, I must say that I do not think there is force in that objection.
speakername: The PRIME MINISTER (Rt. Hon. Sir Wilfrid Laurier).

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: But I asked the right hon. gentleman as to the power of the provincial legislature and the advisability of our invading their jurisdiction for merely incidental purposes.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: I do not see that we are invading any right of the legislature or that they are invading ours. We clearly have power to incorporate such a company as this, and I am strongly of opinion that it is wise for a company of this kind to seek its powers from the Dominion legislature. We can give it more extensive powers and more elasticity-

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: My right hon. friend, perhaps, is forgetting that the provincial legislatures have power to incorporate companies-

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: So it has.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: To incorporate companies for provincial objects.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: We also have power to incorporate companies.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: But I say that every power sought by this company could be given and should be given by the provincial legislature, except the incidental power which may never be exercised or used of carrying on the business of common carriers between Canada and other countries. Are we to invade the jurisdiction of the provincial legislature in respect of ninety-nine subjects because there is one power which may or may not be required by the company and which is within our jurisdiction ? Is it not much better to let the provincial legislature deal with these ninety-nine subjects, and then, if the hundredth power is required, let the company, having secured incorporation from the provincial legislature, come before this parliament and seek this power if it is necessary ? Is not that the better mode of legislation in the interests of good government ?

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: I do not know that it is. No doubt, a great deal of what is done by this parliament could be done by the provincial legislature. The hon. gentleman goes further and says that it should be done by the provincial legislature. I do not see that, in passing this Bill, we are invading a single right of the province. We give them power to do business all over the world, and this company if it is in earnest, as I understand it is, can be better served by securing its powers from this parliament than by securing them from the provincial legislature.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: I think my hon. friend (Mr. Borden, Halifax) if he considers the case more fully will realize that the power to carry on business as a common carrier is absolutely essential to the proper exercise of the rights conferred upon the company in other respects. The company could not get out the material necessary to their work from the Bay of Seven Islands except by the aid of navigation, nor can they hope to export their product in any other way than in steamers. Therefore, the right to carry on the business of common carriers to foreign countries and to other provinces is as essential to their business as the right to manufacture lumber.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: Has the amendment been made to properly safeguard the railway interests ?

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext: Yes.

maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext:
(Translation.) Mr. Chairman, the Bill which is now before the House relates to a company which is seeking to implant a new industry in the county of Chicoutimi and Saguenay. As the representative of that county, I think it my duty to say a few words on the Bill under discussion. It was my Intention at first to have spoken English : but as I am not quite familiar with the English language I thought it preferable to speak French.
The company is going into a territory which is almost an absolute wilderness, and in which there is practically nothing, except fishing, Which is confined mainly to codfish. There is a very small population, and with the exception of a few fishermen and telegraph employees, it consists mainly in Indians who repair to the Bay of Seven Islands several times a year. The Quebec government have gone to great expenditure in order to make known the natural resources of the province, its mineral wealth and its water powers ; and they have brought to light the fact, that on the north shore of the St. Lawrence, there is considerable forest wealth, notably around the Bay of the Seven Islands. There are also good farming lands and a pretty extensive agricultural area. Apart from the surveys made by the provincial goveru-

speakerposition: Prime Minister; President of the Privy Council
maintopic: THE NORTH SHORE POWER. RAILWAY AND NAVIGATION COMPANY.
speechtext:
ment, a few capitalists have also taken tlie means of ascertaining tlie accuracy of those surveys and data The promoters of this Bill, after going to the trouble of making those surveys, have purchased from the Quebec government one thousand miles of limits down in that territory and they have also acquired water-powers. They have, started building a railway and they are putting up a pulp mill, with a force of over a hundred men.
I do not intend to go now into the merits of this Bill, nor do I wish to inquire whether this parliament have tlie power to incorporate this company, or whether we are invading the rights of the local government in so doing. But from the standpoint of the public interest, I am free to say that on the North Shore where there are now only a few fishing settlements, the news that this manufacture was being put up was heard with the greatest satisfaction. This morning, I received several letters from Pointe aux Esquimaux, from Magpie and other places, and these people want to know whether the fishermen, who have no other means of livelihood, could find employment with the company at the Bay of Seven , Islands.
There is no doubt that the whole region of the North Shore will be greatly benefited by tlie fact that this company has acquired this territory and is going to put up those mills ; and on that ground alone, great credit is due to the promoters of this Bill, despite the fact that they are asking for such extensive powers around the Bay of Seven Islands.
It is well known that there are large deposits of magnetic iron ore all along the Moisie river, and that, many years ago, those deposits were worked by Mr. Molson, of Montreal ; but, for the want of transportation facilities, that mining enterprise had to be discontinued. But now, there are many chances of that industry being revived and put on a paying basis.
Some hon. gentlemen object to granting the company the power of carrying on the business of farming and stock-raising. I do not think such objection can be raised in the interest of the settlers. If I understand aright the Bill now before the House, it does not encroach upon the rights of the provincial legislature in that respect.
Now, as long as the provincial law governing the sale of lands is enforced, there is no danger of a monoply being granted, or of this company coming into conflict with the agricultural interests. With the bad record they have been building up for the north shore, which has been described as a barren wilderness, altogether unfit for farming purposes, surely, if this company were not to go into that territory and attempt to carry on a farming business, no private individual, unless he could dispose of unlimited resources, could ever dream of making the attempt. On the contrary,
should the company succeed in its operations, and should its venture be attended with paying results from a farming standpoint, other settlers would undoubtedly follow in its footsteps. As I remarked a little while ago, from the reports of the Crown Lands Department of the province of Quebec, we gather that around the Bay of Seven Islands, there are agricultural lands enough for two parishes to be carved out of them. But that territory is inaccessible except by water in the summer season. Now, the company which is seeking incorporation from this parliament intends to provide communications for the carriage of its agricultural and other products. On the other hand, such settlers as may go into that country will have a considerable market at their door, for the sale of their products, as they will have to supply the wants of all the workingmen in the employ of the company.
I do not think that the powers this company is asking for, extensive as they are, can come into conflict with the interests of the district. Should there toe a monoply, the action of that monopoly would be restricted to the territory to the east of the Saguenay river, which is included in the county which I represent here. Mr.f SAMUEL HUGHES (North Victoria) moved :
That, in the opinion of this House, the best interests of the country demand that the youth of Canada should as soon as possible be afforded opportunity of practicing target shooting ; and to that end, it would he advisable to supply each school district or similar locality with Mr. LEMIEUX.
rifles and the new safety practice ammunition for use on the Peters or similar inexpensive and safe target, where all citizens from the age of fourteen upwards should be afforded opportunity of practice.
He said :	As it is near six o'clock, Mr. Speaker, I shall be exceedingly brief in presenting some observations in support of this motion. All authorities on constitutional law and government agree that one of the greatest dangers to the permanent stability? of any nation is the maintenance of a large standing army. But as every nation must take adequate measures for its defence the alternative of an ettective militia force is offered in substitution for a standing army. Such a militia force might be deemed adequate for the purposes of a country situated as Canada is. Except on occasions of great emergency, I can imagine no easier way to maintain what would be the equivalent of a standing army, than the maintenance of a system by which the youth of the country would be thoroughly trained in rifle shooting, and in the simple and necessary movements in drill which the new strategy and< tactics require. The proposition which I make in the resolution is simple on the face of it. There is a very inexpensive system of target practice provided at the present day, and I wish to see that system placed at the disposal of the youth of our country. In the United States they have what is called the gallery or pratice ammunition, whereby a regular service rifle and short range ammunition can be used without any danger of the bullets doing injury, beyond the range of the target. Of course with the regular service ammunition it would be impossible to use these rifles in practice, but with this ammunition which I understand the Minister of Militia is about introducing into Canada, there is no danger whatever. 1 would point out that the good rifle shots of to-day who are beyond tlie age of forty years, learned the use of tile rifle by snapping caps at: candles. The best shots at Wimbledon in the old days and the best shots at Bisley nowadays learned rifle shooting by snapping caps at candles, and hitting or missing as the case may be; the great thing being the practice in pulling the trigger. If the system which 1 have outlined in the resolution is adopted, it will be of great service to the militia of Canada. I may point out that Mr. Beck, mayor of London, has placed at the disposal of Colonel Peters, the D.O.C., a very handsome trophy to be competed for by the people of the schools in his district.
Is not that confined to collegiate institutes ?

It applies to wherever there are cadet corps in the district. In the city of Montreal there are some excellent cadet corps, among others the Highland cadets of Montreal, and the Highland cadets of Westmount, both of

315&
which corps are maintained without one cent of'cost to the government, and both corps, chiefly the Montreal Highland cadets have furnished nearly one hundred men to the South African contingents, as well as several hundred well trained and well drilled men to the militia corps of that city. In Toronto there is a most excellent cadet corps made up of detachments from the different schools. When I had the honour to be first English master of the Toronto Collegiate Institute years ago, I had a battalion composed of the young men of that institution, and I may say that a number of officers in the city regiments and in different regiments throughout the province received their training in that cadet battalion, Wherever the young men of a country are drilled early in life, experience has proved that they maintain .in after years their zeal and' interest in military matters, and this very fact in Canada has kept the militia force of our country together, iu spite of the many drawbacks that have combatted it during a number of years. It was my intention to speak at greater length, but it being six o'clock I will simply draw the attention of the minister to the necessity for drilling the youth of our country in their early days when their sympathetic interest is most alive to matters of this kind. If we can adopt the system foreshadowed in this resolution, together with the system of training officers which I previously outlined, I am satisfied that Canada will have at her disposal a reserve of men such as no country in the world could equal. I believe, Sir, that without the slightest trouble Canada could turn 1,000,000 men of fighting age and not draw her resources to any greater extent than the Boers have drawn on their resources during the war in South Africa. With such a body of men, Canada would be impossible of invasion, I care not how powerful the enemy might be. I trust the minister will accept this resolution, and with that hope I submit it to his judgment.

I am in entire accord with the spirit of the observations made by my hon. friend (Mr. Hughes). We have in Switzerland an object lesson as . to what can be done in the way of making the militia effective. In that country they have an army of 250,000 men which is exclusively a militia force. I wish, however, to point out that while I am in sympathy with the observations that the hon. gentleman has made, I think we cannot pass a resolution of this kind here, because the matter with which it deals is within the purview and control of the local legislature. Education being in the hands of the provincial legislatures, I think it would be impossible to carry out a resolution of this kind without the consent of the provinces. It seems to me the proper course would be to open up correspondence with the governments of the respective provinces with reference to the matter, and I may say that I had it in contemplation to do this ; and now that my hon. friend has given his views to the House, and has received the assurance I have given him, I think it would be more convenient if the resolution were withdrawn.
