LANCASTER (Lincoln and Niagara) moved that the House go into committee on Bill (3) to amend the Railway Act. He said : In moving that the House

31G0
resolve itself into committee on the Bill, I realize at the outset of my remarks, Mr. Speaker, that I am met with an obstacle but one which I hope on reflection the House will not regard as sufficiently serious to defeat this Bill. I am appealing to the whole House from the decision of the Railway Committee which has not seen fit to report the Bill. This committee perhaps, does not voice the feeling of the House and the report being the vote of only some fifty members, is only twenty-five per cent of those who sit in this House, and is at most a minority of those who are here to-night, or who will be here later.
The law, as, it stands at present, with regard to cattle-guards on highway crossings was admitted by the Railway Committee, as it is all through the country, to be in an improper state. Although the railway companies were originally required to have cattle-guards at all highway crossings, so as to prevent animals straying on the lines of railway, that Act has been so amended as to practically relieve them from that obligation. By the amendments of 1888 and 1890, the whole value of the original legislation regarding cattle-guards was taken away, because these amendments provided that the railway companies shall only be liable for damages, even when they do not have these cattle-guards at their crossings in cases where the animals were properly at the points of intersection between the railway lines and the highway when the accident occurred. In fact the law, as it stands at present, provides that the companies shall only be liable under a circumstance which cannot reasonably be expected to exist at all. it would be more frank and honest to repeal the whole section requiring cattle-guards. I do not suppose that the people would stand it, but still it would be better to do so than to delude them, as we are now doing, with the mere semblance of a protection which has not the slightest existence in reality. It would be far better to say that the railway companies shall not be bound to have cattle-guards at all than to say that they shall only pay damages for not having them, when the animal that happens to be killed ' is properly on the highway,' bearing in mind that the courts have construed those words as meaning in charge of a human being. But it can be easily seen that there is no need for a railway company to have a cattle-guard when the animal is in charge of a human being. No one in charge of an animal will allow it to get on to a railway line, and the legislation in the first instance was no doubt intended to compel the railway companies to take means for preventing animals, that were not in charge of anybody, from straying on their track, and the reason is evident. An animal cannot read the sign 'railway crossing' or appreciate the danger of getting on to a railway line, and therefore it was deemed neees-Mr. LANCASTER.
sary that the companies should be compelled to provide some obstruction against its doing so. I am quite well aware that the speed of railway trains and the necessities of railway service may require changes in the cattle-guards from time to time, but I submit that the railways should be compelled to put up some guard that would be reasonably sufficient to prevent animals getting on to their tracks from the highway, whether these animals be in charge of a human being or not. In the discussion in the Railway Committee, it was urged against the supporters of the Bill I have introduced that it would encourage farmers to become careless and allow their animals to run on the highway and thence on the railway line, and that we should do everything possible to teach the farmers that they must keep their animals off the highway, but we all know that, despite the greatest care, an animal may escape on to the highway. The wind may blow down a farmer's fence, a neighbour coming to visit him may accidently leave his gate open, and thus a farmer, who takes every care, whose gates are fastened and whose fences are good, may still find that by the purest accident one of his animals has wandered on to the highway and thence on to the railway track, and yet though the railway company may have wilfully neglected to provide the protection required by law, he must bear the whole loss.
But then look at the other side of the question. Here is a most positive enactment requiring railway companies to provide sufficient cattle-guards, and they do not comply with it simply because, under the amendments to the law as originally passed, it is scarcely possible for them to be ever required to pay any damages. The farmer is to be held responsible for any accident which might occur, despite his greatest care, and the railways are allowed to go scot free even though they deliberately neglect to comply with the law. The railways are only held responsible where the animals are properly on their tracks and the courts have decided that an animal is only properly on their tracks when it was in charge of a human being and strayed into the danger despite all his care. It must be obvious to everybody that an animal which is in the charge of anybody, would not be allowed to stray into danger, and the railways therefore may violate the law with impunity, whereas the farmer has to suffer the loss should one of his animals, by the merest accident, which the greatest watchfulness cannot always prevent, make its way on to the highway and then to the railway track and be killed.
If the railway companies want the inhabitants of this country to conform to the law they ought-rich and powerful as they are-to set the example and first comply with it themselves, and the effect of my Bill would be that the danger would be met

on botli sides and there would consequently be very little danger of any accident happening" There is no doubt that by the neglect of the companies to provide these cattle guards, when an animal does stray on to a railway track, it runs great danger of being killed, and yet although the railway company was in fault in not complying with the law, the owner of the animal has to bear the whole loss. But even though the owner should be somewhat in fault, why should the chief offender go scot free 7 Anri it must be perfectly evident that the railway companies will not supply those cattle-guards while the law is in its present condition, because people are not likely to do things when they are not subject to any penalty for not doing them. And the law as it stands to-day does not require them except as against a human being to keep a cattle-guard there. The animal comes to that point. If the cattle-guard is not there, there are three directions for it to take-one to the left, one to the rights along the railway track in either case-or straight ahead, where there is no danger. If there is no cattle-guard, there are two chances out of three that the animal will be killed. It is quite as likely to turn to the right or to the left as to go straight ahead, particularly when you remember that the pasture, during some seasons of the year, is better along the railway track than elsewhere. It is not unfair to say that the animal is twice as likely to go down the railway as it is to go along the highway. If it goes down the railway it is pretty sure to get killed, and if it gets killed, no one is practically responsible. The railway will say that the animal was running at large and had no right to be where it was. Though, by Act of parliament the railway is compelled to have-or, rather, is supposed-to have cattle-guards for highway crossings, their answer is : It is true we had no cattle-guard, and so are violating the statute, but we are not liable, because your animal was at large, not controlled by a human being. But, if the cattle-guards are there, is it not plain that the animal will go straight ahead, because the guards will prevent it from going to one side ?	1
know it is said that there is no cattle-guard that will keep every animal from turning upon the railway track. Even though that is the case, yet, if we reduce the likelihood of accident, we are passing good legislation. At the very least, cattle-guards can be put in that will turn a large percentage of the animals and prevent them from getting on the track. So it does not come down to a question whether the owner or whether the railway shall lose the animal, but whether there shall be any animal lost at all. I am not seeking to bring about a state of the law under which a railway will be liable to kill animals. It is not my primary object to cause the railway company to kill an animal and then cause them to be liable
for it; the primary object is that there shall be no animal killed, and so no liability. I seek to create a state of affairs under which both the railway and the owner of the animal will take a certain amount of responsibility, and these responsibilities meeting, so to say, will leave no room for accidents. The law will make it clear that the farmer will be liable if the animal is killed at the point of intersection, that is. upon that part of the earth which is both highway and railway. That being so, he will want to keep his animal at home. But, if it is not killed there, but goes down the railway track because there is no cattle-guard on either side to prevent it, and is killed there, the railway will be liable. This could have no other effect than to prevent the very losses that are making all the trouble. So it is not a question of whether the farmer or the railway shall pay for an animal willy nilly, but whether we shall put responsibility fairly on both parties, so that both parties will work together to prevent accident and loss to anybody. With this general statement of the purpose of the Bill, let me pass on to one or two other matters which I wish to enter on before I sit down.
It was said in the Railway Committee that, if this Bill were allowed to stand over until next year, there would probably be a standard cattle-guard introduced, and made acceptable by Order in Council, or order of the Railway Committee of the Privy Council. or in some other way. Because, it was said, you cannot expect any guard that any railway company will put in to turn every animal. There is something in that, as in a great many other contentions, if you do not carry them too far. But if you carry it to the length of saying that because of that this Bill should not pass, then, with all due deference to those who use it, I submit that it is unreasonable. For, if you make a standard cattle-guard next month or next year, you must pass an Act like this to compel the railway companies to put those cattle-guards in, because, at present, the company is not liable without any guard, if the animal is not in charge of a human being. So, even if I concede that there wM be a standard guard authorized in some official way and that if these guards are put in by the railways, they will prevent animals from straying from the highway to the track, you will still he under the necessity of passing some such Bill as mine. It may not be in exactly the same words, still, it must have the same effect, or the railway company will not be obliged to put in these standard guards.
Now, here is a grievance which is admitted to exist, a grievance so clear that nobody has gone further in opposing my measure than to say that we will get the railways to put in a better guard by next year, if you will allow the Bill to stand. But the grievance being what I have just shown it to be, I ask this House why that grievance

shall be allowed to continue for another year ? Why should the report of the committee prevail ? What good reason is there for saying that it is wise not to proceed further with this measure ? Why should another twelve months go by with this state of affairs allowed to continue, now that the attention of the House has been drawn to it ? Why should not the railways be bound to do something as much for the next twelve months as for twelve months after that, or ten years from now ? Why should the railway companies go on for another year without responsibility while we are waiting for some guttl'd which it may suit the railways to put in ? Why not compel them to put in the best guard they can and leave it to the courts to say whether they have put in a guard that is ' suitable and sufficient ' to turn animals. When the Bill is in Committee of the Whole, the principle having been admitted, if it is thought by the majority of the committee that the wording is not such as to secure justice, amendments can be made. If any amendment can better carry out the object desired, I am here to say, before we go into committee, that any amendment that does not really kill the measure I am introducing will not lie refused by me, will not be opposed factiously by me, because it is not of my own drawing. I do not know that any amendment can be irtwn that will make the Bill any better or that will carry out the idea better than the form of words that I have proposed :
And no animal not allowed by law to run at large shall be held for the purpose of such liability

-that is, the liability mentioned in the Act
to keep up the cattle-gard

to be improperly on a place adjoining the railway if such animal gets upon the railway from the highway by reason of such omission or neglect to maintain such cattle guards or fences at the h ghway crossing.
You will notice that, under this amendment, the railway will not be responsible unless the animal goes upon the land which is the railways own individual property, and which the animal-cannot reach if the railway company have a cattle-guard at each side of the highway where the railway crosses. There is no responsibility upon the railway unless the animal gets right over the land where the cattle-guard ought to be and on the railway itself, on the property of the railway which is separated entirely, or if my Bill passes, will require to be separated entirely from the railway by the cattle-guard. As other gentlemen desire to speak upon this Bill, I will not trespass any longer on the time of the House. I trust that the Bill will he allowed to go to committee and will be passed, if not in the exact language in which I have drawn it, at least in language that will make it as efficient, and will remedy to a reasonable extent the grievance which I submit I have Mr. LANCASTER.
proved exists, and put the responsibility upon the railway which, for the reasons I have stated, ought to be placed upon them.

Motion agreed to, and House went into committee on the Bill.
On section 1.

Mr. Chairman, I have listened with considerable interest and with close attention to the remarks of the bon. member for Lincoln (Mr. Lancaster). I may say by way of apology in offering a few observations to the committee that I certainly do not find in my conscience the accusation that I have taken up a great deal of time of the House thus far this session, so I hope and trust that hon. members will bear with me for a few minutes while I discuss what to some of them seems to be a matter of no importance, but which to others of us who know and understand the feelings and wishes of our constituents, is a matter of considerable importance. I shall endeavour to avoid all those points made by the hon. member for Lincoln, and to confine myself to other phases of the question upon which he has not touched. In the first place many hon. members seem to have the idea that the legislation proposed is along the lines of a return to the old pit-guard. I intend to deal first with this phase of the question. I, for one, if this amounted to a return to the old pit-guard, would most decidedly vote against the proposed legislation. I believe that the pit-guard can find no proper place in railroading at the present day. We know that in the pit-guards of former times water often found a lodging place and froze in the winter, and the road bed was so disturbed as to make railroading uncertain. More than that, when a railway train ran off the track it was quite a usual thing, or a not unusual thing at least, for the trucks of the carriages to plunge into the pit ; the trucks were then pulled from the bottom of the carriage and a frightful accident was the result. With the surface-guard, on the other hand, derailment meant nothing so serious, and the train might run along a good half a mile on the track and then be pulled up with no accident of any consequence. . So I say that a return to the old pit-guard is quite out of the question. Many petitions were laid before this House in the earlier part of the session asking for legislation along the lines of relief to the farmers, and afterwards this House was flooded with a number of petitions from the railway employees praying that pit-guards should not be restored. Mr. Chairman, I say that pit-guards will not be restored, and I propose to show why I think they will not be restored, and if they are not restored, then the petitions of these railway employees are met. Now, I am going to tell you why I think they will not be restored. Some two or three days before this matter was taken up for discussion in the Railway Committee, one

of the great railroads of our country, the Canadian Pacific Railway, was good enough to send each member of this House a very carefully and neatly prepared brief giving its side of the question with regard to cattle-guards ; and I think if, from the four corners of this instrument, I can prove that there will be no return to pit cattle-guards, that there is no reasonable probability of such a return, why then I am proving our case out of the mouths of the witnesses of our opponents, a doubly strong way to prove it. I intend to read some extracts from that brief to bear out my contention that there is no possibility of a return to the old pit-guard if we pass the legislation proposed by the hon. member for Lincoln. In the first place, an official high in the service of the Canadian Pacific Railway-I have not his name here, but hon. gentlemen can find it in the brief to which I have referred- says :
I learn from the railway people

And by the railway people he refers to the employees of the road to whom certain questions were put with regard to cattle-guards.
I learn from the railway people that the dangers to track of the pit cattle-guard are so many that it is practically out of the question for them to use them.
Strong testimony from the same source is that of Mr. H. J. Cambie, no less a person than the divisional engineer at Vancouver, says :
The old fashioned open pit guards with the track rails laid direct on the stringers are complete traps for wrecking trains, and are not worth discussion.
Finally the last statement, which is more important than all the others, is that of Mr. Tye, chief engineer of construction, who says :
The damage caused by one wreck is more than sufficient to offset any loss or injury to stock for many years.
Now, Sir, the whole argument of the opponents of this measure is this, that a return to pit-guards would cause not only one accident but many accidents ; yet here is one of their chief employees saying that a single accident, as opposed to many accidents, would cause a damage to the railway in dollars and cents far exceeding the sum they would have to pay for every head of cattle killed In a number of years. And so since these great corporations well know their own interests, it is fair and reasonable to argue that they would prefer paying for all the cattle they killed to going hack to the old pit-guard which would cause them so much more financial loss. So, I think I have demonstrated from that instrument that there is no danger of a return to pit-guards, and that therefore the petitions of these railway employees against pit-guards are fully answered.
Next, Sir, with regard to the surface-guard ; and here, if I may be permitted to
make a bull-and surely a discussion of cattle-guards might be some excuse for doing so-I will say that surface-guards can be divided pretty generally into three classes :	The first-class where there is no
guard at all, the second-class where there is only a bluff-guard, and the third-class where there has been an honest endeavour to meet the law as it stands upon the statute-book. First, with regard to no guards, I can assure hon. gentlemen that to my personal knowledge, and I only know but a very small part of Ontario, there are a number of crossings at which no cattle guard at all has been installed. What is the reason for this ? The present state of the law is directly responsible for this, and I am going to tell you why. If a cow now gets on to the railway because she is wandering on the highway unattended, even though there be no cattle-guard to stop her, the railway says :
' Oh, your cow was unlawfully on the highway,' and the farmer cannot collect from it. But, if on the other hand, the cow is properly tended by a human being, why, then, she is not going to get killed on the right of way and the railway does not have to pay either way ; so that, which ever way you take it, it is heads I win, tails you lose. The railway company do npt have to pay either way, and they have only to fly in the face of public opinion and not build a cattle-guard at all. But here, they entirely forget the fact that they offer a direct insult to public intelligence which will arouse such a storm of indignation as will compel the peoples' representatives in this House to provide by legislation a remedy for this grievance. Next we come to what is called the bluff cattle-guard.
What ?

That is a term sometimes used In a game called poker. This bluff cattle-guard consists of a succession of slats of wood laid lengthwise and just slanting a little bit. It never stops an animal for one instant ; the animal crosses that guard and goes upon the track. It is perhaps a little better than none at all because it is not such a bare-faced slap at the intelligence of the people. It is an attempt to cajole the farmer into the belief that the railway company are trying to comply with the law. And then, we come to the third kind of cattle-guard which is an honest endeavour to meet the law. This is a metal guard which is reasonably sufficient for the purpose. I have seen a number of these guards on the Canada Southern Railway, now known as the Michigan Central Railway, and they are giving very fair satisfaction indeed, but, these cattle-guards are expensive in their installation and they are very few and far between. Notv, we may go further than that because I have in my hand a copy of the brief with which the Canadian Pacific Railway has furnished us,

I may say that if it be arguable whether we have a cattle-guard which is suitable and sufficient, the legislation proposed by the hon. member for Lincoln (Mr. Lancaster) does not propose any particular kind of cattle-guard, but simply that the law requiring the company to provide suitable and sufficient cattle-guards shall be enforced. Have we got these cattle-guards today ? Let me turn for a moment to this question. Here we have the report of Mr. James Beattie, of the Canadian Pacific Railway, and he says :
There are a number of surface cattle -guards on my division giving the best of satisfaction. This out of the mouth of a witness on the other side. He says :
The new surface guard being put in this season, I am satisfied, is all that could be desired. It lias a neat appearance.
That is nice for the cattle and for the farmers.
And I fail to see how stock can possibly get over it. It is a common occurrence for sheep and swine to walk over the stringers across the old pit-guard. This is impossible with new cattle-guard.
There is a witness of their own saying that he has something better than the pit-guard, and he winds up :
I think every point should be strained to keep to the present system of surface cattle-guards.
Mr. Kilpatrick, in his statement, is equally emphatic :
I would therefore recommend the use of surface-guards very strongly, as if properly put in

If properly put in, mark you.
-they are effective for the purpose intended, and do not become a trap endangering life and property.
This cattle-guard now, if properly put in, will meet the requirements of the law and perhaps if we change the law to make it more important for the railways to put this In, the companies will see that the cattle-guards are properly put in. Finally, Mr. Leonard, himself, says :
One of the most effective surface-guards is the ' Sheffield ' in use on some parts of the division, and the Canadian Pacific Railway guard made standard by drawing No. 16702 last year, is reported as giving good satisfaction. Now, Mr. Chairman, I think I have quoted enough to prove by the evidence furnished by the* brief of the Canadian Pacific Railway that the railway companies have to-day in existence a surface cattle-guard which is suitable and sufficient to turn the cattle back, or if we have not got that perfected cattle-guard, we are at least going so rapidly towards it that if we apply the financial spur to the flank of the rather lazy railway horse, he will be put into a gallop that will take him under the wire a winner with a suitable guard as the prize, and I think It is the members of this House who should see that that spur is properly applied. There Mr. THOMPSON.
have been arguments advanced against this law, and one of the strongest and most frequently quoted which I have heard, is that the farmers of this country will to a great extent resort to this means of selling their cattle. I do not think that any one in this House will seriously entertain that idea for a minute. The farmers of this country have now a very good market for their cattle, and I misjudge their decency and public spirit if to any extent they will adopt this means of selling their cattle. But they cannot be sure of making a sale even if they were purposely to turn their cattle on the highway. If one of these animals goes down the road and is killed at the point of intersection with the railway, the owner gets nothing for the animal. In almost every township in the province of Ontario there is a by-law against cattle being allowed to wander at large upon the public highway. This by-law can be enforced by impounding the cattle found on the highway. I maintain that it is only in the season of the year which is dryest that there is any great danger of cattle getting on the railway, and the reason for that is obvious. Cattle, like human beings, often look for pastures green and pastures new, and so it is that cattle, having eaten the last mouthful of grass on their pasture fields, and seeing the pastures green and pastures new on the roadside, break out and go wandering down the road, and it is in this way that they get upon the railway track provided with defective cattle-guards. Now, Sir, this dry season is the very season when the railway companies have their lines patrolled from one end to the other by their section men who are on the constant watch for fires. These men see these cattle at large, they can impound them, and if they do impound them the farmers have to pay the poundage. I maintain, as a man who knows the conditions existing on the farm, that farmers under these circumstances are not going to allow their cattle to wander about. Now, there was some suggestion made as to an amendment of this Bill along the lines of it being necessary for the railway company to show that the farmer is guilty of negligence in order to shift the responsibility from itself to the farmer. An amendment of that kind I would gladly welcome. It seems to me that if the farmer has been negligent, it is only reasonable that he should pay for his negligence and get nothing for his animal, but the railway should be obliged to show that he has been negligent, provided he has first shown that they were entirely negligent In not providing proper railway cattle-guards. It has been said that this is a matter of very great difficulty for the railway company, that the railway should not be asked to prove any such thing, that it will be very hard for the railway to get witnesses from among the farmer's friends to prove that he wittingly and purposely drove his cow on the railway. There are two sides to every question. One

phase of the law is in regard to fires kindled by railways on the property of farmers. The farmer, if a fire is kindled, has not only got to show that the fire.was kindled by the railway, but he has to show that it was kindled negligently by the railway. He has got to show that the engine which has set this fire alight was false in its construction, and by what evidence can he prove that ? He can only prove it by the employees of the railway, each one of whom is afraid of his life to give evidence, for it may cost him his position. If you reverse the case, and ask the railway to prove from the mouths of the farmers that there was negligence on the part of the farmer whose beast was killed, a great hubbub is raised and it is asked : Is this fair and just to the railway ? I do not wish to say much about the objections raised by other members of this House who do not come from the province of Ontario. I believe that this grievance is largely confined to the province of Ontario, and I judge that from the overwhelming majority that was given by the Ontario members in the Railway Committee in favour of this legislation. I think they were almost as four to one. I appeal to the members from other provinces. If this matter is not a grievance with them let them trust to us in Ontario; let them take our opinion and if they see an overwhelming vote in favour of this legislation by the Ontario members, let them be guided by the view of the majority from Ontario and give us a sympathetic vote, even as time and time again in Ontario we have given them sympathetic votes on some matters of local concern to them. Frequently we are guided by the opinion of the North-west members with regard to this or that railway charter, and we ask a return for that confidence from them now. One member from the Territories said he was going to vote against this Bill because it interfered with the Herd law. I do not believe it does. It proposes a change in the existing law and that existing law does not touch the Herd law at all. Another member said that the Bill did not go far enough and that he would vote against it. That member came from a province by the sounding sea. We are content to take half a loaf; it is much better than no bread', and we would be glad of that gentleman's sympathetic vote even though this Bill does not go as far as he would like. For my part, I never yet had so much pleasure in supporting any legislation as in supporting this. I believe the Bill is in everybody's interest. I do not feel that this Bill will be adverse to the interests nf any of those concerned, and I will tell you why. First of all, it is going to be better for the farmer, because if this Bill becomes law he will get paid for his cattle when they are killed by the railway, whereas before he had to go without compensation, which was often a very serious hardship to him. It is going to be better for the travelling public, which so frequent-100
ly has been invoked in this discussion. The farmers, I may mention, are a large percentage of the travelling public. If we pass this legislation the railways will put in suitable and sufficient guards, and there will be fewer accidents than now, and the travelling public will be killed and injured less often. It will be for the benefit of the railways themselves, for the reason that there will be fewer accidents, and consequently less loss to the railways, and in a year or two the extra expense of these cattle-guards will flow back into their coffers two-fold. I will give another reason why it is better for the railway companies.
I believe, as a business man-though I admit of comparatively little experience-that the sentimental aspect of the case must never be forgotten. I do not care how strong a railway is; it is better for it to have the good-will of the people of the country through which it runs than to have their ill will, and I can assure the railway companies that there is a feeling of indignation in many parts of Ontario to-day against them, because the farmers believe they are tyrannized over by the companies. If the railway companies will remove this grievance, that feeling of antagonism would be effaced, and in time to come there would be a better feeling.

speakeroldname: Mr. L. P. DEMERS (St. John and Iberville).
speechtext:
(Translation.) Mr. Chairman, after having talked the matter over with several people, since this Bill came before the House, I reached the conclusion that it was desirable to amend it by adding after the word ' animal,' in the 9th line, the following words : ' without any negligence on the part of the proprietor.' Under the English common law, contributive negligence debars the injured party from any recourse.
If the railway company has neglected to provide the protection required by law, and if the proprietor was guilty of neglect, each must bear Ms loss.
Under our law, farmers are bound to keep their animals off the highway. The proprietor, whose animal was found straying on the railway track, is supposed to have violated the law. They can take and impound the animal found straying on the railway track, and the proprietor has to pay the poundage. But we also know that, despite the greatest care, an animal may escape on the highway, without the farmer being in the least guilty of neglect. Under the law as it is now, he has no right of action. Under the Bill now before the House and by the Bill under consideration, he shall have the right to sue the company, provided he is not guilty of neglect.
(Translation.) Please read your amendment.
(Translation.) I propose to amend the clause by adding the following words : * without any neglect on the part of the proprietor.'
(Translation.) In addition to those words, it should be expressly stated that by the fact that the animal was not in charge of a human being, the proprietor is presumed to be guilty of negligence.

(Translation.) That presumption already exists ; because the proprietor is always supposed to keep his animals off the highway, and to prevent them from straying on the railway track. Should an animal get on to the railway line and wander about, that is a presumption of negligence on the part of the proprietor.
(Translation.) You then throw the onus of the evidence on the proprietor of the animal.

I understand that the amendment proposed by the hon. member (Mr. Demers) is to the effect that as a condition precedent to recovering damages, it must be shown that the animal is on the track without any negligence of the owner. I submit that this amendment puts the onus in the wrong place. Here is a railway with an enactment against it requiring it to put in cattle guards suitable and sufficient for a certain purpose, and if it does not put them in it should be liable. I submit that the amendment suggested by the hon. gentleman (Mr. Demers) might be' very harmful, and that a provision to say that the animal must be there without negligence on the part of the owner will lead to interminable lawsuits. While one judge would hold that the fact that the animal was not attended was not negligence, another judge might hold that the farmer would have to prove a certain thing a negative, and shrug his shoulders and say : I do not know how you can prove it, but you have to prove it. I submit that this amendment is not fair. What my hon. friend from Haldi-mand (Mr. Thompson) and I want to be provided, is, that where the railway companies have no cattle-guards they shall be responsible, and to say that a farmer must prove a negative will be making a good deal of trouble in the country and creating lawsuits with the chances against the farmer, whereas my hon. friend (Mr. Thompson) and I want to make the law simple and plain. It is the unattending of the animal that is the whple gist of the matter. If you ask the court to hold that a farmer has to prove that it was without any negligence on his part that the animal got there, probably the court will say : It is pretty hard on you, but there is some evidence of negligence here, or how did your animal come unattended when there is a statute which says your animal must not be unattended within half a mile of a highway' crossing- and which statute I am not interfering with.

If my hon. friend's Bill passes, I understand that the law will be that if an animal gets on to the roadbed of a railway, whatever may Mr. DEMERS (St. John and Iberville).
be the negligence of the owner, the presumption will be that the animal is legally and properly' there, and that if an accident occurs, the company' will be liable ?
If there is no cattle-guard.
If there is a cattle-guard, assuming the cattle-guard not toi be sufficient, the company' would be liable.

The railway' company would be responsible, unless the company proved negligence on the part of the farmer other than the negligence of letting the animal be at large. That is a negligence, we must admit ; but it is a trivial negligence. It is no such negligence as the railway company would be guilty of by not having a sufficient cattle-guard, and I do not want the big liability to be killed by the smaller and trival one.
I would like to ask the hon. gentleman if lie considers that there are degrees of negligence ?
Certainly there are.
And they would be so construed in an action ?

Certainly there are degrees of negligence. I do not say they would be so construed by a judge in an action ; but I say there would bei proof of the most positive negligence on the part of the railway company, the deliberate breach of a statute which says that it must have a sufficient cattle-guard-a most malicious, or at least wilful negligence; and against that there would be an accidental, trivial negligence on the part of the farmer whose animal happened to be at large. So my hon. friend, if he wants the Bill to be at all fair to the farmer, should provide that the fact that the animal is not attended on the highway, should be no evidence of such negligence. We must admit that the animal will be unattended once in a while, else the Act would not be required; but that fact alone should not be held to be sufficient negligence to prevent the farmer recovering against the railway company.
Only if tlie railway company itself perpetrates a most wilful negligence.
It is not a question of half or semi-negligence ; It is a question .of the public protection. It is a question whether you are going to obliterate this element of protection to the public.
Might I ask the Minister of Justice if the public interest will not be promoted by compelling the railway companies to keep efficient cattle-guards at then-crossings ?
Yes, and I think that is what we ought to seek to obtain; and we shall obtain that if we carry Out the recommendation of the Railway Committee made at the suggestion of the Minister of Railways.
And if we carry that out, there will be nothing done within the next twelve months.
Yes, there will.
It seems to me, representing a city constituency
Don't you let cattle run at large ?

No, we do not let cattle run at large in Toronto. It :seems to me, as I understand the matter, that if an animal gets on the right of way of a railway company, and is killed, the farmer is completely out of court, and has no chance at all to make a good case against the company.
No, that is not correct.
The court never gets so far as to ascertain whether the company7 had a proper and efficient cattle-guard at the crossing or not.
Oh, yes, it does.

Perhaps the Minister of Justice will tell us how and when it does ?
I think we ought to legislate not specially in the interest of the farmers or in the interest of the railway company, but in the interest of the public generally; and if the law now requires the railway company to have an efficient cattle-guard at each crossing, I think parliament should insist on that being done. It is a fact, as I have been advised by many lion, gentlemen on both sides of the House, that since the onus of proving that the cattle were not improperly or illegally upon the highway has been placed on the farmers' shoulders, the railway companies have allowed the cattle-guards to deteriorate. One hon. member on the way- from Smith's Falls to Ottawa the other day, told me that he could point 'out several crossings where there were no cattle-guards at all; and if a farmer's cattle,
through accident, strayed out of his field aud got on to the railway right of way and were killed, the. farmer would have no recourse whatever. He would have to prove that the cattle were legally where they were when they were killed, and he could not do that. The lawi as it is at present throws the entire responsibility upon the farmer of proving that the cattle were where they had a right to be, and unless he could do that he would have no recourse against the company. It appears to those who try to look dispassionately at the. matter that there is something wrong with the law as it now stands, and that under it the farmer does not get fair play; and it is an insult to him to say that he desires to have the law amended for the deliberate purpose of letting his cattle on the track in order to have them killed. He can do better by selling them than by trying to collect damages from a railway company, and I do not think that statement should be made again. I am firmly convinced that under the law at present, as it is interpreted by the courts, the farmer does not get fair play. I am in favour of the amendment of the hon. member for Lincoln. If it is wrong, a year's experience will show wherein it is wrong, and then, if necessary, we can have it amended and made what it 'ought to be.

In dealing with this matter, my view7 is that we should not endeavour to complicate the question so as to involve a farmer in a lawsuit on every occasion when an animal is killed. We should make the law as clear as possible, so. clear in fact that the farmer himself can interpret it and know whether he can recover damages or not. I believe that the law can be made so clear that there need be no litigation, and with that view I propose to move an amendment to the amendment. Reference has been made by my hon. friend from Haldimand (Mr. Thompson) to the old pit-guard. I am not going to discuss that point because I understand that the general public do not approve of this guard. The railways are also very much opposed to it because it has a tendency to weaken the track, and with rapidly running trains, it is next to impossible for the railway companies to continue that style of guard." The law, as it now stands, provides simply for a suitable and sufficient guard. The difficulty is fo determine when a guard is suitable and sufficient. I do not propose to interfere with the wording of the Bill of my hon. friend from Lincoln (Mr. Lancaster). I am quite satisfied that we should enact every word of it, but I propose to add something, which I think is only fair to all parties concerned. We are not here to legislate in a way that will simply secure damages to a farmer if his animal be killed. What we want is to legislate so as to prevent animals getting on the railway tracks and being killed, and if we can do that we will be doing a great deal

more than simply enabling the farmers to recover damages. We have also the interest of the travelling public to consider, whom we desire to protect, and for whose protec- . tion it is necessary to have an adequate guard. I, therefore, propose to move, in amendment to the amendment, that the following words be added to the Bill :
Provided, however, that no liability shall accrue against any railway company for damages caused at any point where a cattle-guard approved by the Railway Committee of the Privy Council has been erected and maintained.
If a railway company at any time puts in a guard which has the approval of the Railway Committee of the Privy Council, then the company is exonerated from all damages should animals be killed. If a farmer should own a horse, accustomed to jump hedges, hurdles and ditches, which would get over the best guard you could devise, you could not expect a railway company to pay damages, should such an animal be killed in spite of all its precautions. Or if a farmer should allow a breachy steer-an animal that ought to be kept in stable at all times- to remain out in the field, and that animal should break through the fences and get over the railway guard the railway company should not be held responsible. I have sufficient confidence in the Railway Committee of the Privy Council to believe that it would only approve of the very best guard that can be obtained, either in this country or the United States or any other country, and the farmers would know that once a railway company had put up a guard of that character they would have no claim for damages. On the other hand the railway companies, having complied with the law, would feel that they had protection against any claims, and this would act as an inducement to them to put up the guard required by the Railway Committee. I can see no other solution of the question than to adopt a standard guard and the Railway Committee of the Privy Council Is the most competent tribunal to decide what that standard should be. If that committee cannot determine this question, no other court can. Once the Railway Committee have decided upon a Standard cattle-guard, the farmers will know just where they stand. I believe that the farmers would then be perfectly satisfied. I have conversed with some of them during the past few weeks on this matter, and I did not find one say that such a law would be unfair. When the best guard that could be found was put in, the railway companies should be protected against damages, but until they complied with the order of the Privy Council they should be held liable. I may be told that the railway companies will not put in a guard. Well, if they will not, they will he liable for all damages, but the moment they do so, they are afforded all the protection that can be demanded by them.

This question has been so fully discussed that I need hardly say much about it. The fact that so many petitions have been sent to this House during this session from all parts of Ontario is plain proof that the farmers will not be satisfied unless some action is taken by this parliament regarding this cattle-guard business. All points have been discussed, from the farmer's point of view and that of the railways and the travelling public, this evening. Next to the travelling public, the farmers are more interested than any other portion of the community, because their cattle are liable to be killed, and if so, no damages can be recovered by them under the present law. If a proper cattle-guard be erected, as can be done and as has been done before, the travelling public will be sufficiently protected. The travelling public will be safe, because no cattle can get on the railway to be killed, and the farmers will be safe for their cattle will not be killed unless upon the intersection of the highway if they wilfully allow the animals to stray. The farmers are too much Interested in this matter to allow the railways to be unprotected in the manner they have been. The men who man the railway trains, engineers, conductors, firemen and others-nine out of ten of them-are farmer's sons. Moreover, farmers make up a very large proportion of the travelling public. Altogether the farmers are more interested in the safety of the railways, perhaps, than any other class. I think it only right that at this session we should determine that the railways shall place cattle-guards. As it is at present, when a man wishes to drive cattle down the road, as I stated to the committee, he has to take two or three men with Mm to keep the cattle from getting on the track. Cattle driven away seek to return home, and they take the first opening and make a rush hoping to get away from their drivers. If there are no cattle-guards, they get on the track, and if a train comes along, the cattle are killed and the lives of the people in the train endangered. But, if the cattle-guards were there, the cattle would pass on across the track, and would not be killed, nor would there be that risk of killing passengers in the cars. I think this matter should be decided and decided at once.
