speechtext: The hon. member (Mr. Lennox) is perfectly right, and I recall the case now that he has reminded me of it. The hon. member for South Sim-coe (Mr. Lennox) was on his feet when I asked him to sit down.

I wish to call your attention and the attention of the committee to the fact that the amendment read from the Chair was not the amendment as read by the hon. gentleman who moved it, and, therefore, I submit, it is not under discussion. While X have the floor, which seems to be a desirable position to-night, I will make a few remarks, with the permission of the committee. If the amendment of the hon. member for Halton had remained in the form in which he read it. I would be prepared, although it is not exactly what I would like, to support something along that line. Although I do not entirely agree with his view, I think there ought to be some sort of compromise in a matter of that kind.
I do not understand the farmers of this country to ask any more than what is reasonable. and they seldom, in my opinion, ask as much as they are entitled to. Therefore, I think X have the concurrence of the committee in saying that when the farmers do come and ask for something that they really need to redress a grievance, the matter should receive ready consideration at the hands of this committee. That there is a great grievance we need not argue. I think that is admitted on all sides. I wish to say one thing and say it very distinctly, and that is that I repudiate as strongly as I can the accusation made against the farmers by the argument that they want to sell their cattle by driving them or permitting them to go on the track. That argument has been advanced many times, but I think that any hon. member who says that does not understand the farming community in this Dominion. 1 need not say that they are an honest class and that in coming before the committee they are seeking redress for a grievance under which they have laboured for fourteen years-a great deal longer I am bound to say, than they ought to have submitted to it. The question whether there can be any instance in which a farmer could have redress in case his cattle are killed by going on the railway track at a point where there should be a cattle-guard, lias been suggested by the Minister of Justice (Hon. Mr. Fitzpatrick) I hear every opinion of that hon. gentleman with great deference ; and would have been glad to hear him state any instance where a farmer could recover. But, in the absence of such a statement from the hon. gentleman it will not be deemed presumptuous in me to express my own opinion. From the study I have given the matter, I understand that as the law now is, if there are no cattle-guards and the cattle go down along the track and are killed, the farmer can not possibly recover. And for this reason, which is very plain-that, by the fact of the cattle going down the highway unattended tne law was broken. Therefore, there is no lawyer who would for a moment advise the farmer in such a case to bring action.
We do not need to speculate upon the law in that regard, because the law lias been so decided in more than one case in the province of Ontario, and also in Manitoba. So then we have this fact, that we have a law upon the statute-book which says that the railway company shall have suitable and sufficient cattle-guards, and yet if they do not have them, as they have not had them, they can snap their fingers at the public as well as at the farmers, that they can openly violate the law, and there is no possible redress in case of cattle straying upon the highway and thence upon the railway track. Now that is a matter which I submit cries for immediate redress.

My hon. friend speaks with a great deal of authority, as coming from Ontario, because these rul-

ings do not apply in the province of Quebec, where we have not the doctrine of contributory negligence. But he says, assuming that the railway company is in default and that the farmer is not, and an animal gets on to the track and is killed-there is no recourse against the railway company. Now let us assume that the farmer is in default, that the railway company has got a suitable cattle-guard, and that the animal gets on the track and is killed, what would be the result in that case ? As I understand the kon. gentleman, he says the farmer is out of court because of contributory negligence. Is that not his opinion ?
Yes, not because of contributory negligence.
On the doctrine that he has not properly taken care of his animals.
Because it is contrary to the statute, as I understand it. It amounts to the same thing.
Practically the same thing. Now if the railway company meets with an accident and their cars are thrown into the ditch, where is their recourse ?
None whatever.
It seems to me there are two sides to this question.
My hon. friend has put two or three questions to me.
Take the converse of my hon. friend's case.

In the last case, you say, supposing there is damage to the railway, in what condition do the company stand ?
I may say that if my hon. friend thinks that is a matter for eonsideraaion, it should be attended to. But my hon. friend from Lincoln is dealing with a matter which is specific and clear in itself. But I may tell my hon. friend that if my recollection of the statute is correct, if a farmer through negligence allows his cattle to get upon the railway, he is liable in case damage is done to the company. But coming back to what is more important, the farmer cannot recover at the present time in case cattle go from the highway upon the railway, notwithstanding that the company have been guilty of a direct breach of the statutes. That is the position of the law to-day.
That is where both parties are in default.

I am stating what is the fact, I am not inquiring into the cause. The fact and the law are that to-day if a farmer's cattle go upon the highway, whether by accident or design, unattended, and are killed upon the railway, the farmer cannot get any redress.
Nor the railway company either.

speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada

speechtext: One moment. What I say is this, there is a penalty in case the farmer's cattle get upon the highway, that is, he runs a risk of having them killed at the place of intersection, and when they are killed there he has no redress. Now my horn friend says there are two wrongs, and there is a great deal in that argument, but not enough to stop this Bill. The farmer is wrong in having his cattle upon the highway at all, and the railway company are wrong in not having a proper cattle-guard there. Now the question is, what is the proximate and immediate cause ?
Apply the doctrine of civil law and you have got an answer.

I am going to apply the doctrine of civil law to my hon. friend if he will wait. Now we have these two wrongs and I submit that the doctrine of the immediate and proximate cause is the one which should govern in a case of this kind. The farmer's cattle getting upon the highway may or may not meet with an accident. If there was a cattle-guard there they certainly would not meet with an accident at the point where they are killed-
If they were not straying they would not be there.

Excuse me, if it were not for the absence of a cattle-guard they would not be killed between the two crossings upon the railway. It is plainly laid down that if a person is negligently crossing a railway track and is not acting with reasonable diligence the railway may not be liable ; yet, if the company couid have averted the consequence of the plaintiff's negligence and did not, the company is liable. Now. if the railway company had done what the law prescribes it would not have been guilty of statutory negligence, and this accident between the two highways never would have occurred. Therefore I say you should compel the railway company to comply with the law, you should say to them, ' We will compel you to comply with the law, and if you do not, then you will be liable in ease cattle are killed between the highway crossings.'

I think this measure is one of the most important that has been brought before parliament this session. It involves not only damage that may be done to cattle struck by a railway train, but damage that may be done to the train itself, and it involves the life of the travelling public and of railway employees. These are matters we must consider when we approach this question. For three days this matter was discussed before the Railway Committee. Upon the last day the Minister of Railways and Canals made a statement, which to my mind seemed most reasonable : it was that the government would undertake during recess to find out what was the best cattle-guard or cattle-guards, and then at the next

session to enact a law compelling all railway companies to put in one or other of these guards. I think that in the discussion of this question one very important provision of the railway law has been entirely overlooked. Section 194 of the Railway Act says :
Fences should be erected and maintained on each side of the railway through such township, of the height and strength of an ordinary division fence, with openings or gates or bars or sliding or hurdle gates of such width for the purpose thereof, with proper fastenings at farm crossings of the railway, and also cattle-guards at all highway crossings suitable and sufficient to prevent cattle and other animals from getting on the railway.
1 mean to say that there is no gentleman who can tell us, that there Is no railway man who can tell us of a cattle-guard which is sufficient to answer the requirements of that section. It is admitted to-day that no cattle-guard has been devised which is sufficient. The nearest approach to it is the old pit-guard and everybody is unanimous in admitting that that guard causes dangers which are far greater than the compensation of the safety to the animal.
Are the words ' suitable ' and - sufficient.'

' Suitable ' and ' sufficient.' A cattle-guard Is not sufficient that permits an animal to get over it. Under section 271, If cattle are imporperly on the highway and not properly attended and the railway kills them at the point of intersection, the owner has no action. That is where the highway crosses the railway, and experience has shown that if cattle are at large, if they are loose, and if they are upon the point of intersection and the train approaches, in nine cases out of ten, they will not turn to the right or the left, but they will rush madly over whatever obstruction there may be in the shape of a cattle-guard, and upon the line, and it is there that they will be killed. The first thing we have to consider about this statute is that it lays ail impossible burden on the railway company, and whenever an Act lays an impossible burden on an individual or a company, that Act, to a certain extent, becomes nugatory. I submit that the root of the whole evil is in the impossibility of the railway company to comply with the provisions of the law as it stands to-day, and if you are to remedy that evil the Governor in Council, or the Minister of Railways and Canals, or the Railway Committee of the Privy Council, must lay down exactly what shall be a suffcient cattle-guard, giving its dimensions and specifications. Then, in case the company shall put in one of these guards or any such guard as may be prescribed by the Railway Committee of the Privy Council, and as it will then be possible for the railway company to comply with the Act, the disposition of parliament would be to force them to do it. There, I submit, is
the root of the whole evil. I submit that the railway law as it stands to-day is nothing more than the common law of England. Here is the obligation resting upon the farmer on the one side to take care of his cattle, here is the obligation resting on tlie railway company to see that reasonable precautions are taken not to let these cattle get upon the line of their railway. If one of these parties neglects the obligation that rests upon him that party is liable for any damages which may result, but if both parties are negligent, then, surely, neither party should have an action against the other. This section is a section which has been in the Act since we have had a railway law. It is true that the phraseology of subsection 3 has been altered, but the only effect of the alteration is to lay a little heavier burden on the railway company. Subsection 3 as it stood formerly was as follows :
Until such fences and cattle-guards are duly made and completed, and if after they are so made and completed they are not duly maintained, the company shall he liable for all damages done by its trains and engines to cattle, horses and other animals, not wrongfully on the railway.
The amendment of 1890 makes use of different phraseology and says that :
If the company omits to erect and complete, as aforesaid, any fence or cattle-guard, or if, after it is completed, the company neglects to maintain the same as aforesaid, and if, in consequence of such omission or neglect any animal gets upon the railway from an adjoining place where, under the circumstances, it might properly be

That is the only difference, and I submit a careful consideration of that amendment shows that it lays a heavier burden on the railway company. Now, the amendment which has been proposed here by the hon. member for Lincoln (Mr. Lancaster) proposes, in effect, to say that in so far as railway crossings are concerned-he does not deal with fences, or any neglect so far as fences are concerned-but so far as cattle-guards are concerned, cattle shall not be considered improperly in an adjoining place simply because they are at large upon the highway. In other words, it would leave the law in the position that there is a provision which the company cannot perform. The company cannot put a cattle-guard there which would be a sufficient obstruction to cattle going upon their line. Then, if cattle going along the highway pass over this guard which is not sufficient to keep them away and they are killed, the company is liable in every case, no matter whether the cattle of the fanner were upon the highway by the grossest negligence on his part or not. I say that as between the company and the farmer it is not a fair or just provision, and it is proposed to change one of the safest principles of common as well as railway law. Then, there is the trainman upon the engine, or on the car. Has he anything

to do with this cattle-guard ? Has he anything to do with these cattle that are running at large, and yet his life is jeopardized, as are also the lives of the travelling public, because there are all manner of disasters which may overtake them. I read in the newspapers the other day of a cow which strayed near a station in the vicinity of Toronto, was struck by a locomotive, hurled against a carpenter who was at work nearby, breaking Ills back and killing him. Although that cow was at large through the gross negligence of the owner, we would have this state of affairs that here is a man killed by this cow being at large through negligence, yet the owner can recover damages against the railway company. I think I am in a position to speak with some slight authority upon this question. In the first place, I was born and bred on a farm, and in the next place, I have the honour to represent a county which is largely agricultural, through which, from one end of it to the other, a railway passes, another railway crosses within nine miles of its entire breadth, and still a third railway is being built. I have had some experience in operating a railway, having operated a railway for some six or seven years under an order of the court, and I make the statement with all deference to lion, gentlemen who have expressed contrary opinions that it would be a matter of the greatest misfortune. not only to the travelling public but to the farmers themselves, if we were to adopt this amendment to the Railway Act. I am sure that the farmers in my county and that the farmers in Nova Scotia do not demand anything of the sort. They are reasonable enough to see that the only way you can have safety is by keeping the burden on both sides. Hold the farmers to their duty, hold the farmers to the exercise of ordinary care and diligence in keeping cattle off the track, and hold the railway company to its duty in maintaining cattle-guards.

The hon. gentleman (Mr. AA'ade) says : Hold the railway company to its duty. How are the railways bound by any obligation ? How are the railway companies liable if they do not put in cattle-guards ?
Mr. AA'ADE. I have read the section and the hon. gentleman has seen it.
I read the section also, but I asked the hon. gentleman (Mr. AA'ade) to state a case if he can where the railway would be liable if they had not a cattle-guard.	[DOT]
I could state many such cases. In any municipality where there is no (by-law prohibiting cattle! running at large, the owner of the cattle would have an action against the company.
At common law they could not run at large.

The principle of the common law in most of the provinces is, that the owner of the cattle must fence them in. The opposite, however, prevails in my province, and cattle are allowed to run at large unless there is a by-law of the municipality against it. I think, by their civil code, the province of Quebec is iu the same position as under the common law in England in that regard. But mark you; we are making a law here not only for Ontario and Quebec and the maritime provinces, but for the whole Dominion, and for that vast section of country where cattle roam at large month after month. If you pass this law, then if a railway company had not cattle-guards over the prairie sections, the owner of a herd of cattle which is allowed to roam at large, could recover from the railway company if his cattle were killed. A railway company cannot fence along its line in the prairie sections, and so if you pass this law it will be absolutely unworkable in some parts of the Dominion, and it would land the farmers of the country in chaos, confusion and litigation.

If a farmer .is driving liis cattle along a road taking them to market, and they get on a railway track and they are killed because there is no cattle-guard; what recourse has the farmer under the present law ?

Under section 271; if he is driving cattle along a road he is required to have them in charge of some person who is reasonably capable of managing them, and if be does that and his cattle are killed on the railway track through the waut of a cattle-guard, the railway company is liable under the law as it stands to-day. That is a fair provision. The owner should have his cattle in charge of one reasonably capable of managing them, and if through his negligence in not complying with that provision his cattle are killed, he should be responsible for the damages that he sustains. One of the first cases that I have to try at the approaching session of court is an action brought by myself for a client against a railway company, for the value of a herd of cattle which were killed on a line of railway. 1 have advised my client that he is able to recover against the railway company. I say that every protection is here in the Act if we eliminate the word ' sufficient ' from the section we are now considering. If the government prescribed one or more cattle-guards and said that these cattle-guards would be ' sufficient,' then I say that we will have met the whole difficulty.
Now, we come to this question of a sufficient cattle-guard. I listened with great attention to the very excellent speech made by my hon. friend from Haldimand (Mr. Thompson). He discarded the pit-guard, and I believe we all agree that the day of the old piDguard is gone, but we have to search around to ascertain what is the best guard.

31S6
What kind of guard is now most largely used in the maritime provinces V

The old pit-guards are used on the old lines of railway, but the guard which is in most general use on the new lines, and which is deemed to be the best for all practical purposes, is what is called the gridiron.
What is used on the main line of the Intercolonial Railway ?
They have the old pit-guards which were originally put in, but I understand these have been changed wherever a new one is required and the gridiron is substituted.
Is this gridiron guard made of iron or wood ?

It Is made of wood. There is a large gridiron guard with spikes in it, but that lias been found to injure the cattle, and the gridiron which has been found to work fairly well is made of wood, but it is not a sufficient guard because it does not keep the cattle off the track in all cases. Let me tell my hon. friend that the man who to-day would invent a sufficient cattle-guard which would comply with the provisions of section 94. would be a millionaire to-morrow, because I have not the slightest doubt that every railway in the Dominion would be anxious to adopt it. It is not fair to say that railway companies do not care whether the guards are there or not. To assume that, we would have to assume that the companies are utterly regardless as to whether they destroy the property of others or not; we would have to assume that they are callous as to whether they destroy life or not, and we would also have to assume that they are regardless of the destruction of their own property. The amendment to the amendment moved by the hon. member for Halton (Mr. Henderson) has a great deal in it to commend itself to my judgment. After all, it is only the proposition that was put by the Minister of Railways before the committee the other day, when he said he would undertake on behalf of the government to ascertain by commission or otherwise the examination of all cattle-guards in use on the continent of 'America if necessary, and when one or more of the best guards were selected ha would undertake to introduce an Act next session requiring the railway companies to put in the prescribed guard. Some hon. gentlemen may say :	How are you to compel the railway companies to put in that guard. That is the easiest thing in the world. You can provide, that if they do not put the guard in within a certain time after the passage of the Act they shall be liable to a penalty for every day of such neglect, and the penalty can be made so high that they must put in the required guard. You could make them liable for damages if you will, but I hate interfering
with the well known principle of common law. We could accomplish the result by making the railway companies liable for heavy penalties to be recovered by any person suing. If that be done we will remedy the wrong complained of by the farmers.
I will take the responsibility that such a provision will be absolutely satisfactory to the farmers I represent. If we do that we will be compelling the railway companies to do what they should do. We will have then dealt fairly between the railway company and the farmers, and in dealing fairly between the two we will have had due regard for the safety and interests of the travelling public and the men who are employed upon the trains.
Will the hon. gentleman (Mr. Wade) explain to the committee what he means by saying that he will take the responsibility that it will be satisfactory .
I said :	Before my constituents in my own county. I suppose almost any gentleman would understand what I meant by that, gome hon. MEMBERS. Almost.

In view of the fact that I represent a rural constituency and that I have had petitions sent to me with regard to this matter which I presented to this House, I wish to say a few words on this question. A lot of energy has been wasted to-night in trying to show that the law as it stands with regard to protection at railway crossings is not sufficient. I think it is generally conceded that the law at present is not sufficient, and that it is against the interests of the farmers of Canada. But it is needless for us to say that the law as it stands is not sufficient and that it should be amended as proposed by the hon. member for Lincoln, becuse if we amended it in that way we would just be putting it as far wrong the other way. The railway company should be placed in the same position as an individual. I do not think there is an hon. gentleman here who would say that they ought to be put in a worse position than an individual. Under our present municipal law. it enables individuals to establish what is called a lawful fence ; and if an individual puts up a lawful fence, he is absolved from any consequences that may come from that, and he can collect damages should his neighbours' cattle get over such. So with a railway company. They ought to be given the opportunity of putting up a lawful fence, and if they do that, they should be absolved from any consequences. But, under the proposal of the hon. member for Lincoln, no matter what kind of a fence the railway company should put up, if anything should happen they would perhaps be held liable. I do not think any hon. member of this House would say that is fair. I go further and say I do not think there is a farmer in the country would say that is fair. The farmers of this

country do not wish to put even a railway company in a worse position than they would desire to be put themselves. That is my position clearly in this matter. I do think the government ought to take this subject in hand, and declare what would be a lawful fence, so that the company would be put on a fair footing with other individuals. The hon. member for Lincoln deserves credit for bringing this matter forward, and I understand that the government next session are prepared to take it up and deal with it, and I think he ought to accept the statement that they will do something to put it in that position. I think his Bill might be so amended as to provide that a legal fence would be declared by the Railway Committee of the Privy Council, and a certain date might be fixed when the law would come in force and by which time the railway company would be absolved from blame if they put up such a fence.

I occupy a somewhat similar position to that of the hon. gentleman who has just resumed his seat. I have not any doubt that there exists a grievance and that by reason of the law as it at present stands. But I also think that by reason of an agitation which has been propagated throughout the province of Ontario by a newspaper, and by reason of the fact that certain hon. members of this House have been given by that newspaper a certain prominence and have obtained a certain kudos, the question has been unduly pressed, and they have apparently been afraid lest they would lose that kudos if they would accept any fair or reasonable compromise which might be suggested. It may be charged that, because I was referred to in terms anything but flattering by that newspaper last week, I speak as I do now. But I repudiate the charge before it is made. Perhaps it will be said that is because I have an uneasy conscience ; but I repudiate this because I took the same position at the time it was proposed that this question should be disposed of in the House, and not referred to the Railway Committee, which was before the newspaper article appeared, that I would not stigmatize myself as a member of that Committee by saying that that body was not capable of dealing, or would not properly deal with the question. When the measure first came before the Railway Committee, I feared I would not be able to be present when it would be disposed of, and I spoke on that occasion saying that if an amicable arrangement could not be arrived at, and the railway companies would not accept any compromise, I would be prepared to support the hon. member for Lincoln's Bill ; and I still occupy that position. The newspaper to which I refer did not give me credit for saying that; but said that the member for North Simcoe was a runaway. Therefore I feel it necessary to state now the position which I occupy. I agree entirely Mr. GILMOUR.
with the hon. member for East Middlesex (Mr. Gilmour) that there is a grievance, but that by legislating as the hon. member for Lincoln suggests, we would make the law go as far in the opposite direction as it does in favour of the railways at present. If that is_ the case, and if after three days' discussion in the Railway Committee and two or three hours' discussion here. hon. members cannot reach a fair and reasonable compromise, though both sides agree that a fair and reasonable compromise is possible, the difficulty must be to put it into proper words. What is the grievance ? Only that a certain standard cattle guard is not maintained. If a standard cattle guard can be got, which is capable of keeping cattle off the railways, and that cattle guard is maintained, then the grievance is obviated and the difficulty is removed. Now, it is said that the Act as it stands at present does not arrive at that result, and in that I entirely agree, because unless the cattle, when on the highway, are in charge of an individual, it is held that they are not properly there. Consequently, the railways have in no way kept up their cattle guards. But as the Minister of Justice puts it, if the cattle, through the negligence of the.farmer, being the first step of negligence, get upon the highway, and stray further, and then get upon the railway, then it is said that the farmer should profit by his negligence. I do not think he should ; and in this I entirely agree with the hon. member for East Middlesex, who himself is a farmer, and who knows the feeling of the farmers. I have also had the opportunity of discussing this matter with the farmers of my constituency, and they entirely agree with what he says, that no farmer desires that farmers as a community should be allowed to take advantage of their own negligence. Nor do the railway companies I should hope, desire to take advantage of their negligence. If they do it is our duty to legislate so that they should not. But surely it is possible to arrive at a compromise whereby the farmer and the railway company should be on the same basis as individuals, and the law should be as fair towards the one as it is towards the other. If we agree in that, why should not some fair compromise on these lines be drafted ?
It seems to me that the English language is not so barren that a fair compromise cannot be framed ; and I am informed-the hon. member for Lincoln will correct me if I am wrong-that when his Bill was under discussion before the Railway Committee on the third occasion, on which occasion unfortunately I was not present, it was suggested that the matter should be referred to a sub-committee, composed of seven on one side nominated by himself, and five on the other side. Seven members to be appointed by himself and five members representing the opposite view, and he would not accept that proposition.
That is not correct I have never heard of it before.

Then I must have been misinformed. At all events, amendments [DOT]were submitted along the lines of the suggestion made by myself on the first occasion the Bill was before the committee, and the hon. member would not agree to anything of the kind. Am 1 correct in. that ?

An amendment was suggested by .one of the members from Essex-I think the hon. member for South Essex. I argued, as I have done to-night, that the fact that the animal was unattended should be no presumption of negligence, and I did so with regard to the clause suggested, namely, that a farmer could only recover when there was no negligence on his part. If it were provided that the fact of an animal being unattended was no presumption of negligence, I was willing to accept the clause proposed, but I did not know that the hon. member for North Simcoe had anything to do with it, and I have not seen any proposition of the kind to-night.

The information that came to me was that tile hon. member for Toronto (Mr. Clarke) had either conveyed or was asked to have conveyed a message to my hon. friend from Lincoln to the effect that a sub-committee should be appointed to be composed of seven members, selected by my hon. friend himself, and five holding the contrary view, to deal with the measure. He would then have the thing in his own hands, and the sub-committee would be bound to report. But of course, if that message did not reach him, I have nothing more to say on that point. But it seemed to me that this difficulty must be worked out on the basis of compromise, and I thought it unreasonable on the part of my hon. friend not to have accepted the offer which I supposed was made. X come now to the other suggestion, to which my hon. friend from Lincoln has referred, and for whicli I 'do not claim any credit. It was that if the cattle got on the road by reason of the negligence of its owner, he could not recover ; and I admit that the further suggestion of my hon. friend was a good one, and I think that if those holding opposite views could be got together, a compromise could be arrived at to the effect that if in the opinion of a court or a court and jury, if the case is tried by a judge and jury, the owner of the animal was found guilty of negligence, he should not recover, but that the fact of an animal being unattended on the highway should not be taken as a presumption of negligence. If such an amendment as that meets with the approval of the hon. gentleman, it seems to me the difficulty is removed. That I think would be a solution of thef difficulty, satisfactory to both sides, but should it be impossible to arrive amicably at a reasonable arrangement and no compromise be arrived at, I am prepared to support the Bill of my hon. friend from Lincoln.

In view of the number of amendments put forth to-night and the statement made by the hon. Minister of Railways in the committee, I think that we ought to have some statement from some member of the cabinet, in the absence of the Minister of Railways, as to whether or not the government are prepared to carry out the promise made by that hon. minister in the committee. In my judgment, it would be in the interest, not only of the farming community but of the travelling public, that this matter should be seriously considered before any legislation be passed affecting it. It is not fair to say that hon. gentlemen who may take a different view from those who slip-port this measure is opposed to any legislation that will remove the difficulty. I do not think that there is an hon. gentleman in this House who is opposed to legislation on this matter that will relieve or remedy the grievaupe. We are all agreed on that point, but where we disagree is as to what is the best way to remedy the grievance and do away with the complaints of the farmers. It has been stated here that this is to be an amendment to the General Railway Act of Canada and is to apply to the different provinces throughout the Dominion. But when we hear men from Manitoba and the North-west Territories and the other provinces outside of Ontario say that this Bill does not meet their views, it seems to me that it is the duty of the government and especially of the Minister of Railways to make a thorough investigation and so amend the Act that it will meet the requirements of all concerned. No doubt the railway companies have been more or less negligent in the matter, and where they have been negligent the head of the Railway Department should see as far as possible that they carry out the law. The fact of cattle roaming at large and causing accidents on lines of railway has been pointed out, and no doubt in such cases the farmers cannot claim any damage for the loss of their cattle. But, on the other hand, are not the consequences far more serious than the loss of cattle, when, in consequence of cattle thus roaming at lai'ge, they are struck by railway trains, and damage is done to the property of railway companies and the lives of travellers imperilled and injured and sometimes lost ? All the cattle-guards from here to the Pacific coast will not prevent accidents of that kind. The animals are on the highway, through the negligence of their owners, and by reason of that negligence loss of life occurs and great damage to railway property, so that the actual plafcing of a cattle-guard would not prevent accidents in that way. But the great difficulty of passing legislation in this House is that you may possibly, if you are not very careful, frame it of such a character that it will make the farmer more negligent than he is, and thereby cause great danger to the travelling public as well as the property of the railway company. I can speak from my railway experience, and

1 have known of many incidents, in which, by reason of the negligence of those who own stock throughout the country, serious accidents have occurred, and therefore I look upon this question as a very important one which should be seriously considered by the head of the Railway Department before any action can be taken. If the first minister will say that they are prepared to thoroughly investigate this matter and bring down legislation next session that vvill remedy the grievance, 1 am prepared to support the government in that course. But if they are not prepared to make any such declaration, I will have to be guided on other lines entirely, but until I have their declaration I am not prepared to state what course I shall take now.

1 was on the sub-committee last year that was appointed to consider this Bill. 1 took the view then that it was not one which should become law. One of the reasons I gave has been pretty well gone into, and that is that while it holds the railway corporation liable for negligence, it relieves the other party, no matter what negligence he may be guilty of. When tills Bill came up this year, I proposed an amendment on these lines, namely, that we should insert the words ' Without any negligence on the part of the owner or person in charge of the cattle.' That amendment did not seem acceptable to the promoter of the Bill, and after considerable discussion, the hou. Minister of Railways and Canals said that if it were allowed to stand over until the next year, some steps would be taken to see that sufficient cattle-guards were placed, where necessary, by the railway companies. Now I take the view that what we all desire is not only the safety of the cattle but the safety of the public, and that safety we will best provide by having the most efficient cattle-guards that can be procured.
In the year 1900 on some 18,000 miles of railway in the Dominion of Canada upon which there were 21,500,000 passengers carried, there were only seven persons killed through accident-less than one for every three millions of passengers carried. That is creditable not only to the railway corporations of this country, but also to the farmers, that they, on their part, have observed the law and kept their cattle from running at large on the highway. For, on looking at the statistics for the United States of America, I find that there were 530 accidents through cattle getting on the railway track. I say we should legislate in the interests of the great public Of which the farmers form very much the largest portion; and we should not put upon the statute-book any measure which would be a retrograde measure and open the door, if I may use that word, for accident. For, as this Bill is framed, it would induce men to be careless and. perhaps, to permit their cattle to run at large, knowing that no matter how care-Mr. INGRAM.
less they had been, if the judge or jury say the cattle-guard is not sufficient they would recover damages. I am very sorry the Minister of Railways is not here to-night, for I would like him to make the statement in the House which lie made in the committee. It was upon that statement that I voted to let the matter stand over until next session, because I believe that what we want is a proper cattle-guard, the best possible cattle-guard that we can obtain. And we want it left to the Minister of Railways or the committee to say what is a proper and sufficient guard. We find that, in the United States of America, the railway commissions of the different states inspect the cattle-guards and decide what is, or is not sufficient guard. If they pronounce the cattle-guards sufficient, that is the end of it. But, if this Bill were to become law, we should be in a difficulty as to whether a cattle-guard was sufficient or insufficient, judges or juries in different places taking different views. Therefore, I take it that it is in the interest of the public and in the interest of the farmers themselves that this Bill should be left in the hands of the government, that is, if the government assure us that they will take it up and give it every consideration, and come down next session with a Bill that will give the relief that is looked for.

When I hear the hon. member for East Middlesex (Mr. Gilmour) and tlie lion, member for Halton (Mr. Henderson), for whom I have the very highest respect, and who understands the position of the farmers in Ontario mucli better than others who are speaking more strongly for them, I am bound to say that it is evident opinion is not all one way. There is no cyclone in this matter; there is no reason why we should not take time to consider what we are doing. As both these hon. members said, we must look at the case fairly. The difficulty with a number of gentlemen who have spoken is that, under the fearful pressure of a number of people clamouring for a change in the law, they have forgotten that they were going to pass an Act of parliament, and have substituted this clamour and their own feelings in response to it, for the legal words and the legal facts
Where is the clamour in this Bill ? If it is not in proper legal phraseology, will the hon. gentleman point out where it fails ?
The clamour is from the hon. gentleman (Mr. Lancaster) and he is substituting his clamour
Let me ask the hon. gentleman if he did not say that we had introduced mere clamour into this legal document ?

I said they were substituting this clamour to give an appearance

of strength to tlieir speeches instead of considering the cold words of an Act of parliament. You could not put clamour into an Act of parliament.
I thought the hon. gentleman said we had.

I was about to refer to what the hon. member for Haldimand (Mr. Thompson) said. He called upon the members from the lower provinces, because this was an Ontario matter, to join him. Does he want us to do violence to the principles of common law because there are people in Ontario who wish it ? If the hon. gentleman wants that, he should provide that this Act shall apply only to Ontario; and, then, if Ontario is unanimously for it, I will not say a word against it. Now, we in the lower provinces have a fair number of miles of railway. Yet I have not received a single letter in support of this Bill, nor have I seen a single word about it from my own portion of the country. I have no doubt the difficulty arises In Ontario, and perhaps elsewhere. But we should never forget, as the hon. member for Annapolis (Mr. Wade) has so well said, that it would be idiotic for us to remedy one difficulty merely by creating another. Legislation" should be designed to remove difficulties, not to create new ones, that, perhaps, would be worse than the others. Wise men will seek to lessen a difficulty, or do away with it if possible, but will not pass legislation that will merely irritate the other side and create a difficulty greater than the cure. So, as one member from the lower provinces, I cannot accept the flattering invitation of the hon. member for Haldimand that, because he and others want it we should support this amendment to the law. We must consider what the effects of the change would be, not in Ontario only, but elsewhere. It seems to me that this would put the farmer in a position of unfair advantage, and as the hon. member for East Middlesex said, there is no farmer in Canada who wants that. It is not necessary for us to talk about the farmers being honest; the farmers of Canada need no defenders here or elsewhere. Under the wording of this Act, it would be possible for any man to recover whose cattle were killed. Even the present law is mixed up with this phrase of ' suitable and sufficient,' but if you will read the words as they appear in this Bill :
And no animal not allowed by law to run at large shall be held for the purpose cf such liability to bo improperly on a place adjoining the railway if such animals get upon the railway from the highway by reason of such omission or neglect to maintain such cattle-guards or fences at the highway crossing.
In connection with this, you must read ' by reason of neglect to maintain such suitable cattle-guards or fences.' That, it appears to me. would make it almost impossible to defend any action, and I do not
think any hon. gentleman would want that.
I think we should accept what the Minister of Railways has said. But, if that is not accepted, i will vote for the amendment of the hon. member for Halton, for that is the next best thing in my opinion. I would not have taken up time but that I wished the committee to understand that we who come from the lower provinces can look at this question not only from the point of view of our own provinces, but from the point of view of the general effect of this statute.

I come from a county through which three railroads run the fastest trains probably in the Dominion of Canada. Upon this question of cattle-guards there has been a good deal of feeling' amongst the farmers on account of the number of cattle killed. I have a number of letters which I could read from farmers who have had cattle killed, and are unable to get any recompense from the companies. The discussion this evening has turned largely on the question of negligence. Now I will cite a case to show how far the farmers are justified .in complaining of the law as it stands at present. Mr. W. D. McCrim-mon, of Glenroy, on the Canadian Pacific Railway line, writes that one stormy night liis fences were blown down, the cattle came from the rear of the farm, passed down the road, and got on the track, and laid down on the track, and six thoroughbred cattle were killed toy a train before morning ; and he could get no recompense for those cattle because they were illegally on the track.
Supposing the train was thrown from the track and several lives lost, who would he liable then ?

I am merely discussing the question of negligence. Was that a case of negligence ? I think that was a case where the railroad were clearly liable under the law, because if they had had a sufficient cattle-guard those cattle would not have got on the track and would not have been killed. I believe that in 90 percent of the cases where cattle are killed it is in the night time when they have -strayed upon the track in that way. There are very few cases indeed where cattle get upon the track in broad daylight. The root of the matter, as the member for Annapolis (Mr. Wade) says, is the question of the sufficiency of the cattle-guard. So far as the farmers are concerned it is usually in the might time that their cattle get upon the track, and through no negligence of their own. Railroad men will almost invariably tell you that very few cattle get upon the track in the day time. They do not feed upon the track, but upon the side of the track. In the night time, if they get on the track, they lie on it because it is a warm place. I think the law should be made to protect the farmer whose cattle, by no negligence of his own, break out of the field and stray upon the track. Another

question we have to consider is the sufficiency of the cattle-guard. The hon. member for Haldimand (Mr. Thompson) read extracts from the railroad people to show that they used efficient cattle-guards. Some railroads claim they have sufficient cattle-guards when they have only a few wooden slats laid upon the track. The member for Annapolis spoke about a gridiron cattle-guard. That gridiron cattle-guard is used in the United States to-day, and is recognized as sufficient by the law, but it is made of steel. The Canadian Pacific Kailway had a large number of thse steel gridiron cattle-guards upon their track, and *so did other roads in this country, but they were expensive, ami so they substituted for the steel gridiron cattle-guards a few six inch boards put down upon the track which would allow any animal to walk over. The law said the company was not obliged to pay for animals that went upon the track so long as they had a semblance of a cattle-guard, so long as they had a few boards there. That was considered sufficient under the law to .protect the company from liability if cattle strayed upon the track and got killed. These facts are well known to every railroad man. The gridiron cattle-guard made of steel is to-day practically an effective cattle-guard, but it is an expensive one, and it was dispensed with because the law admitted as sufficient a few cheap boards put down as a cattle-guard which would cost 75 cents, whereas the other kind would cost $20. That is the kernel of the whole matter. If the railroads had these gridiron steel cattle-guards in use we would not have this discussion to-night.

A good deal has been said *on both sides with regard to what eonsti-tutes a sufficient cattle-guard. I think it is high time we should amend the law and put it in such a shape that the people will know when they have a sufficient cattle-guard. It has been said that if a- man is driving cattle over the road and they get killed, the owner can recover from the company. That is not the case. There was a case where the judge decided that if a man was in charge of the cattle, that was sufficient to protect the owner, and there being no cattle-guard on the railway and the cattle being killed, the owner had no recourse I think the motion of the hon. member for Halton (Mr. Henderson) should be adopted, as I think that will protect the farmers of this country.

Exception has been taken to the amendment which I introduced, because I failed to read the latter portion of it. I was under the impression that in committee it was not necessary for a member to read his amendment, but that 'it was the Chair who read the amendment in putting it. Therefore in my opinion the amendment is properly before the House even though I failed to read the last Tew words.. My intention was :to fill in the
date with the 1st day of April, 1903, and when motion is put from the Chair. I would like those words to go in, in order to allow tlie railway companies time to comply with the requirements of the Act. 1 am sure the committee will be reasonable in a matter ot that kind. No hon. member would expect the railway companies to be prepared to-morrow, or in two weeks, to put in the guards which the Railway Committee of the Privy Council might decide upon. They must have reasonable time, and we must as reasonable men, deal in a reasonable way with the companies. It was suggested by the member for Annapolis that my amendment was along the line of what was suggested by the Minister of Railways and Canals in the committee. 1 think it is somewhat different. In the Railway Committee I had my amendment prepared, but I did not catch the eye of the Chairman soon enough, and another suggestion was made before I could read my amendment. My amendment was different from that suggested by the Minister of Railways and Canals, in that I proposed immediate legislation. 1 favoured that, because the petitions that were sent in this year asked for legislation this session, and my desire was to comply with the prayer of those petitions. Consequently I moved an amendment in the Railway Committee, but it was held that I was not in order at the time. Perhaps X was not, I did not find fault with that ruling. Rut I take the opportunity of moving it here. Now I desire to say here that impolicy is a standard guard. 1 am not so particular how that standard is obtained. I would call that a solution of this difficulty.
I would prefer that it should be obtained along the line I have suggested. I thiuk that would be .the better and the more acceptable way. I think this the more speedy way, because, before parliament could be able to pass an Act next year, we would have these guards put in by the railway companies, and if the railway companies did not put them in, they would become liable under the Bill of the hon. member for Lincoln. If I cannot secure a standard guard in that way I am not going to oppose the policy of securing a standard guard in any way as soon as possible.

Under the circumstances and in view of the opinion of a good many hon. gentlemen on both sides of the House, I think it perhaps would be the best I could do in the interests of the country, as I understand the country's interests to accept the amendment of .the hon. member for Halton (Mr. Henderson). It seems to me, that if not quite the same thing that the Minister of Railways and Canals (Hon Mr. Blair) has suggested, it is almost the same thing and the difference is that we get a certainty now instead of an uncertainty, not meaning to impute for >a moment that the hon. Minister of Railways and Canals would not carry out next year what

he intends to, bnt there is, as the hon. member for Halton has said, a great demand at present for a certainty in regard to this question, and I think the country will not be satisfied with any promise that may mean anything or nothing as far as practical results are concerned. Having in view the fact that the hon. member for Halton, as it seems to be understood by members on both sides of the House, adopted the main part, or the gist of the contention of the hon. Minister of Railways and Canals when he provides that if there is a standard guard provided the company shall not be liable under the amendment which I am asking the House to pass, I think the House will say that I have accepted as reasonable a compromise as I could be asked to accept understanding the rights of the parties to be as I have understood them to be. The effect will be that a company will be liable until that standard guard is put in and not liable afterwards if the standard guard is put in and maintained. The Act will not go Into force until April next; that is practically what the hon. Minister of Railways and Canals undertook to do next year. I can see no objection that he can make to putting that in this year provided that it does not go into force until next year. We get practical legislation through and are really carrying out what a great majority of hon. members want. It will suit the hon. member for Middlesex (Mr. Gilmour), it will suit the hon member for Annapolis (Mr. Wade) and I think it will suit the hon. member for Guysborough (Mr. Fraser), although he did not go so far as these other hon. gentlemen in saying what would suit him, while he was arguing for a compromise. I hope it will suit the hon. member for North Simcoe (Mr. McCarthy), because he says that we are compromising in the sense that we let the railway company off if they provide what the Railway Committee of the Privy Council has said is a proper guard. Provided that they do that I think it is fair that they should be let off if the guard is .sufficient. I think therefore they all ought to accept the amendment of the hon. member for Halton and be unanimous for once this session.

It is admitted on all sides .that there is an evil from which the farming community is suffering at this moment, an evil which the hon. member for Lincoln (Mr. Lancaster) is trying to remedy by the Bill to which he has called the attention of the committee. But, at the same time, it seems to me to be admitted on all hands, also, that the remedy provided by this Bill is not adequate and will not meet the object which it is intended to serve. This proposition has been made to me very clear by the speeches of my hon. friend from Halton (Mr. Henderson), my hon. friend from Middlesex (Mr. Gilmour) and my hon. friend from Guysborough (Mr. Fraser),
gentlemen for whom I have the highest respect and who can speak with authority upon such questions. It has been made clear that the farming community do not want to have one-sided legislation. They want legislation which will work both ways and which provides that the company shall perform their duties and that the farming community should perform their duties also. Such being the case, I may call the attention of the House further to the fact that it seems to me, that, at this moment, my hon. friend from Lincoln is scarcely in order in the proceeding which he asks the committee to adopt. I will call the attention of the committee to the rules of the House upon this subject. This is a private Bill introduced by the hon. member for Lincoln.
speakername: The PRIME MINISTER (Rt. Hon. Sir Wilfrid Laurier).

speechtext: No, a public Bill.

It is a public Bill, but to serve an object as to which the procedure applied is the procedure of a private Bill. Certainly, it is a public Bill. It has been referred to the Railway Committee of the House. That Bill was read a second time with the distinct reservation that the House would not commit itself to the principle of the Bill, but that the principle of the Bill should be discussed by the Railway Committee, and that we should receive the report of the Railway Committee before we committed ourselves to the principle of the Bill. Now, I find that this Bill was not reported on favourably by the Standing Committee on Railways :
Your committee have had under consideration Bill No. 2, an Act respecting telephone companies, Bill No. 3, an Act to amend the Railway Act, and Bill No. 28, an Act respecting telegraph and telephone companies, and recommend that the said Bills be not further proceeded with during the present session.
That is the report which we have before us, and my hon. friend altogether ignores this report. He has not even, so far as 1 have been able to follow the discussion, and I have followed it with a great deal of care, and I do not recollect that the hon. gentleman has referred to this report.
In moving the House into committee I did.

In a very casual way, but he has not moved to have the report set aside. While he stated that the report of the committee made certain recommendations the recommendation was that the Bill should not be proceeded with this session. He has ignored this, has put it aside and has asked the committee to proceed with the Bill as if the Bill had been reported upon favourably by the Standing Committee on Railways and Canals. I suppose if the Railway Committee had reported favourably be would have said that the Bill should have been taken clause by clause and section by section by this com-

mittee and that the Bill should be accepted. Now, my hon. friend proposes that we should do the same thing. There is no difference whatever in his procedure to day. If the report of the Railway Committee had been favourable to his Bill he would have proceeded just as he is proceeding now, he would have asked that the Bill be taken section by section and approved by the House. But, the report has been against him. The Railway Committee have not reported the Bill, but have recommended to the House that the Bill should not be proceeded with this session. He puts that aside altogether, he does not take it into account and he asks the committee to pass the Bill as if the Bill had been reported favourably by the committee. What shall we do with this report ? What is the object of it ? Why did we refer this Bill to the Railway Committee ? We referred it to the Railway Committee to have the opinion of the Railway Committee upon the subject. The opinion of the committee is that we should not proceed with the Bill this session. For my part I have always maintained that the best course for the House, is to support its committee unless very strong reasons can be shown to the contrary. I am informed that the reason why the committee would not entertain the Bill this year was because of the statement made by my colleague the Minister of Railways : that in his opinion the best way to deal with the question was not to support the legislation presented by the hon. member (Mr. Lancaster) but to decide first what proper cattle-guards are and then to say that they shall be adopted. The Minister of Railways reported to me that he had stated to the committee that during the recess he would take means to collect information as to the best cattle-guards in existence; that he would appoint experts to ascertain that, and that next session he would introduce legislation dealing with the matter. In fact that matter was arranged between us beforehand and the Minister of Railways spoke by authority of the government. The pledge which the Minister of Railways took before the committee, I now take on behalf of the government before the House. We shall during the recess employ experts and collect information to find out what is the best cattle-guard that can be devised, and we shall then undertake to deal with the question. 1 think that is the best course which can be followed under the circumstances, and I would submit it to the approval of my hon. friend from Halton (Mr. Henderson). This is a very important question, and a question which should be carefully considered. For my part, I am strongly of the opinion that the legislation now before us, will fail of its object, and I agree with my hon. friend from Middlesex (Mr. Gilmour) that the best way is to provide that the railway companies shall have the best cattle-guards. men, and particularly to the hon. gentleman from Halton, that we will serve best the ends which all of us have in view by following the course that has been suggested by the Minister of Railways, and allow the matter to stand until information is collected during the recess, when the question can be dealt with next session.

Has the right hon. gentleman considered that if the amendment of the hon. member for Halton (Mr. Henderson) is adopted now, the law will be ready at hand next year. The amendment will not in any way prevent the government from putting into execution its resolution of examining into which is the best cattle-guard during the recess, but on the contrary it will facilitate the government in doing so. The amendment will thus give us a law coming into force next parliament, and will allow us to put the results of the inquiries of the government into force without legislating again. In the province of Quebec it is a very serious matter for us. I will not say that it has been agitated as vigorously as in the province of Ontario, but there is no doubt that we have suffered a great deal from this defect in the legislation. This grievance has been mentioned very often in the House. We have petitions asking for immediate legislation, and in my opinion the proper course for the House to pursue now is to adopt the amendment of the hon. member for Halton.

I am aware that this grievance is not confined to the province of Ontario. We have suffered in the province of Quebec perhaps as much as in other provinces, but at the same time I would suggest that there would be more security, if, since we have to wait under any circumstances, we should wait a little longer and have before ns the result of the inquiries which will be made. In the meantime we will try to find an adequate remedy for the wrong, and if we incorporate that remedy in the statute-book next session, no harm will be done. The hon. gentleman (Mr. Henderson) has suggested that he would be quite satisfied to leave the selection of the cattle-guard to the Railway Committee of the Privy Council. That may be. but I think we can leave it with greater safety ito parliament itself. Next year we will be able to prescribe the nature of the cattle-guard in the law, and it will occur to everybody that that would be still more satisfactory than if we now adopt the amendment proposed by the hon. gentleman (Mr. Henderson).

I do not think that the right hon. gentleman has gone so far as the Minister of Railways in his statement. I understood the Minister of Railways to say that he would carefully weigh the law as it affected the different provinces, and that he would be prepared at the next session to come down with legislation that would

remedy the evil in so far as it affected the wliole Dominion.

I cannot say that I have discussed that point with the Minister of Railways and Canals, but I did discuss with him the question of the cattle-guard. If we provide a safe cattle-guard then we can very well adopt the reasoning of my hon. friend from Halton, that if there is an animal who jumps over a proper cattle-guard he should bear the consequence.
The right lion, gentleman would greatly reassure me if he would tell me that next April we will have a law in force remedying this evil.

I think I can answer that. If the hon. gentleman will not delay the session then we will possibly have such a law in force next April. That matter rests with the hon. gentleman himself. If he delays the session of course the law may not be in force in April.
It would be in force at once, if I had the power.

I understand the government is ready to remedy this evil and bring down legislation next session. Otherwise I should be compelled to vote on the question now, but if the right hon. gentleman gives that promise I will stand by the government.
